div.p: IF IT BE NOT GOOD, The Diuel is in it. A New Play, AS IT HATH BIN lately Acted, with great applause, by the Queenes Maiesties Seruants: At the Red Bull.
Flectere si nequeo Superos, Acheronta mouebo.
LONDON, Printed for I. T. And are to be sold by Edward Marchant, at his shop against the Crosse in Pauls Church-yarde, 1612.

div.head: TO MY LOVING, AND LOVED FRIENDS and fellowes, the Queenes Maiesties-seruants.
div.p: KNowledge and Reward dwell far a-sunder. Greatnes lay once betweene them. But (in his stead) Couetousnes now. An ill neighbour, a bad Benefactor, no paymaister to Poets. By This Hard-Houskeeping, (or rather, Shutting vp of Liberalities Doores,) Merit goes a Begging, & Learning starues. Bookes, had wont to haue Patrons, and (now,) Patrons haue Bookes. The Snufft hat is Lighted, consumes That which Feeds it. A Signe, the World hath an ill Eare, when no Musick is good, vnles it Strikes vp for Nothing. I haue Sung so, but wil no more. A hue-andCry follow, his Wit, that sleeps, when sweete Tunes are sounding. But tis now the Fashion. Lords, look wel: Knights, Thank well; Gentlemen, promise well; Citizens, Take well; Gulles, Sweare well: but None, Giue well, I leaue therefore All, for You: And All (that This can be) to You. Not in hope to Haue; but in Recognition of What I Haue (as I think) Already (your Loues.)

Acknowledgement is part of payment sometimes, but it neither is, nor shall be (betweene you and me) a Cancelling. I haue cast mine eye vpon many, but find none more fit, none more worthy, to Patronize this, than you, who haue Protected it. Your Cost, Counsell, and Labour, had bin ill spent, if a Second should by my hand snatch from you This Glory. No: When Fortune (in her blinde pride) set her foote vpon This imperfect Building, (as scorning the Foundation and Workmanship:)
you, gently raizd it vp (on the same Columnes,) the Frontispice onely a little more Garnished: To you therefore deseruedly is the Whole Frame consecrated. For I durst sweare, if Wishes and Curses could haue become Witches, the necke of this Harmles Diuell had long a goe bin broken.

But I am glad that Ignorance (so insolent for being flattered) is now stript naked, and her deformities discouered: And more glad, that Enuie sits maddingly gnawing her owne Snakes, whose Stinges she had armed to strike Others. Feede let her so still. So, still let the Other be laughed at. Whilst I (pittying the One, and not Dreading the Other,) send these my Wishes flying into your Bosomes; That the God of Poets, may neuer pester your Stage with a Cherilus, nor a Suffenus, (Males, Eminent in nothing but in Long Eares, in Kicking and in Braging out Calumnies) vpon whose Cruppers may be aptly pind, That Morrall of poore O●nus making Ropes in Hell, whil'st an Asse stands by, and (as he twists) bites them in sunder. But if His Versifying Deity, sends you Any, I wish they may be such, as are worthy to sit, At the Table of the Sun. None els.

I wish a Faire and Fortunate Day, to your Next New-Play (for the Makers-sake and your owne,) because such Braue Triumphes of Poesie, and Elaborate Industry, which my Worthy Friends Muse hath there set forth, deserue a Theater full of very Muses themselues to be Spectators. To that Faire Day I wish a Full, Free, and Knowing Auditor. And to that Full Audience, One Honest Doore-keeper. So, Fare-well.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: WOuld t'were a Custome that at all New-playes
The Makers sat o'th, Stage, either with Bayes
To haue their Workes Crownd, or beaten in with Hissing,
Pied and bold Ideotes, durst not then sit Kissing
A Muses cheeke: Shame would base Changelings weane,
From Sucking the mellifluous Hypocrene:
Who write as blinde-men shoote, by (Hap, not Ayme,)
So, Fooles by lucky Throwing, oft win the Game.
Phoebus has many Bastards, True Sonnes fewe,
I meane of those, whose quicke cleare eyes can viewe.
Poesies pure Essence, It being so diuine,
That the Suns Fires, (euen when they brightest shine)
Or Lightning, when most subtillie loue does spend it,
May as soone be approchd, weyed, touchd, or comprehended.
But tis with Poets now, as tis with Nations,
Thil-fauouredst Vices, are the brauest Fashions.
A Play whose Rudenes, Indians would abhorre,
I●t fill a house with Fish wiues, Rare, They All Roare.
It is not Praise is sought for (Now) but Pence,
Tho dropd, from Greasie-apron Audience.
Clapd may he bee with Thunder, that plucks Bayes,
With such Foule Hands, & with Squint-Eyes does gaze
On Pallas Shield; not caring (so hee Gaines,
A Cra●d Third-Day, what Filth drops from his Braines.
Let Those that loue Pans pipe, daunce still to Pan,
They shall but get long Eares by it: Giue me That Man,
Who when the Plague of an Impostumd Braynes
(Breaking out) insects a Theater, and hotly raignes,
Killing the Hearers hearts, that the vast roomes
Stand empty, like so many Dead-mens toombes,
Can call the Banishd Auditor home, And tye
His Eare (with golden chaines) to his Melody:
Can draw with Adamantine Pen, (euen creatures
Forg'de out of th'Hammer, on tiptoe, to Reach vp,
And (from Rare silence) clap their Brawny hands,
T'Applaud, what their charmd soule scarce vnderstands.
That Man giue mee; whose Brest fill'd by the Muses,
With Raptures, Into a second, them infuses:
Can giue an Actor, Sorrow, Rage, Ioy, Passion,
Whilst hee againe (by selfe-same Agitation)
Commands the Hearers, sometimes drawing out Teares,
Then smiles, and fills them both with Hopes & Feares.
That Man giue mee: And to bee such-a-One,
Our Poet (this day) striues, or to bee None:
Lend not (Him) hands for Pittie, but for Merit,
If he Please, hee's Crownd, if Not, his Fate must beare it.

div.head: IF THIS BE NOT A GOOD PLAY, THE DIVELL IS IN IT.
div.stage: Enter (at the sound of hellish musick,) Pluto, and Charon.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: HA!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What so.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Ile be thy slaue no longer.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What slaue?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Hels drudge, her Gally-slaue. I ha' wore,
My flesh toth' bones, bones marrowles, at the Oaer
Tugging to waft to'thy Stygian empire, Soules,
Which (but for Charon) neuer had come in Sholes,
Yet (swarmde they nere so,) them on shore I set,
Hell gets by Charon, what does Charon get?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: His Fare.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Scuruy fare, ile first cry garlick.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Doe:
And make hel stinck, as that does hither.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: If I doe!
Some like that smell, my boate to shore ile pull;
Not worke a stroake more.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Not touch a Scull.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I ha' no doings: Graues-end-barge has more,
And cartes as good as any are in hell;
I feare th' infernall riuers are frozen or'e
So few by water come: els the whores that dwell
Next dore to hell, goe about: besides, tis thought,
That man to find hell, now, new waies haue sought,
As Spaniards did to the Indies. Pluto, mend
My wages, or row thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Vgly, grumbling slaue,
Haue I not raisde thy price? yet still do'st craue?
Such bold braue beggers (heard off ner'e before
Are thy fares now, they teach thee to beg more.
Thy fare was (first) a halfe-peny, then the soules gaue thee
A peny, then three-halfe-pence, we shall haue thee
(As market-folkes on darth,) so damned-deere,
Men will not come to hell, crying out th'are heere
Worse racke then th'are in tauernes: why doest howle for mony?

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: For mony: Ile haue ij. d. for each soule
I ferry ouer; Im'e old, craz'd, Stiffe, and lam'de,
That soule thats not worth ijd. wou'ld twere damb'd.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: I will haue it, or lye still,
If Charon fill hell, hell shall Charon fill:
For Ghosts now come not thronging to my boate,
But drop by one and one in; none of note
Are fares now: I had wont braue fellowes to ply,
Who, (hack't and mangled) did in battailes dye.
But now these gallants which doe walke hells Rowndes,
Are fuller of diseases, than of woundes.
If wounded any take my boate, they roare,
Being stabd, either drunke, or slaine about some whore.
Thats all the fight now.

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Charon.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Get thee gon:
That call'd for.

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Charon.

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: Ball not. Ile come anon.
Hagges of hell gnaw thee with their fowle furd-gummes.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Pluto, no wonder if so few hither comes?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Why:
Gingerly: See See,
One of thine owne promooters, (with hawkes eyes,
That should for prey be watching) here snoring lyes.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: With a mischife! cabind! a fury.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Ile Ferret out more.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Another: looke: dancing a bawde on's knee.

sp.speaker: Shack.
sp.l: I doe enquire if rich bawdes Carted bee
On earth as well as poore ones: I sleepe not Pluto.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Twist stronger-knotted whips, Ile wake you (slaues!)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Two of thy Summers dead drunke here too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou lyest.

div.stage: Charon. Lurchall and another Spirit comes vp.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I come: If I must worke, let these
Thy Prentices, plye their occupation,
T vphold hells Kingdome, more must worke then one.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ha; Are there whipping-posts for such as dwell
In Idlenes on Earth, and yet shall Hell
(As if wee tooke bribes here too,) let such passe▪
Ile haue you tawde: Is not the world as t'was?
Once mother of Rapes, Incests, and Sodomies,
Atheisme, and Blasphemies, plump Boyes indeed.
That suck'd (our Dams brest) is shee now barren? Ha▪
Is there a dearth of villaines?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: More now then euer?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Is there such penurie of man-kinde Hell-houndes▪
You can lye snoring.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Each Land is full of Rake-hells.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: But sholes of Sharkes eate vp the Fish at Sea.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Braue pitchy villaines there.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Yet you playing here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No, No; most awefull Pluto.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Were you good Hell-hounds, euery day should bee
A Symon-and-Iude, to crowne our bord with Feasts
A blacke-eyde-soules each minute: were you honest diuel▪
Each officer in hell should haue at least,
A brace of whores to his break-fast: aboue vs dwell,
Diuells brauer and more subtill then in Hell.

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.l: Weele fill thy pallace with them.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ile trye that: goe:
Rufman, take instantly a Courtiers shape
Of any country: choose thine owne disguize
And returne swiftly.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Shackle-soule weare thou
A Friers graue habit.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Grumshall walke thou
In trebble-ruffes like a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So: tis don.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: The barres of our latigious Courts had wont
To crack with thronging pleaders, whose lowde din
Shooke the infernal hell, as if 't had bin
An earth-quake bursting from the deepe Abisse,
Or els Ioues thunder, throwne at the head of Dis
(The God of gold,) for hiding it below,
Thereby to tempt churles hither. Nor did we know
What a Vacation ment: continuall terme
Fattend hels Lawyers, and shall so againe.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Command vs.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Fly into the world:
As y'are in shapes transformde be so in name,
For men are our sides onely: be you the same;
〈◊〉 thee to Naples, (Rufman), thou shalt finde
A Prince there (newly crownde,) apply inclinde de
To any bendings▪ least his youthfull browes
〈◊〉 at Stars only, wey down his loftiest boughes
With leaden plome●● poison his best thoughts with tast
Of things most sensuall; if the heart once wast
The body feeles consumption; good or bad kings
Breede Subiects like them: cleere streames flow from cleere springs.
Turne therefore Naples to a puddle: with a ciuill
Much promising face, and well oylde play the court diuell.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Ile doo't in brauery: if as deepe as hell,
Thy large eares heare a Land curse me, my part's playd well.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Fly Shackle-soule.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: To the Friery,
Best-famde in Naples for strict orders: throw
What nets thou seest can catch them: Amongst 'em sow
Seedes of contention, or what euer sin
They most abhor, sweate thou to bring that in.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: A wolfe in lambe skin leapes into the rout,
Bell, booke, or candle cannot curse me out:
Ile curse faster than they.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Doe:

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Be thou a cittie-diuell, make thy hands
Of Harpyes clawes, which being on courtiers lands
Once fastend, ne're let loose, the Merchant play,
And on the Burse, see thou thy flag display.
Of politicke banckruptnesse: traine vp as many
To fright vnder it, as thou canst, for now's not any
That breake, (theile breake their necks first) if, beside
Thou canst not through the whole citie meete with pride,
Riot, lechery, enuy, Auarice, and such stuffe,
Bring 'em all-in coach'd, the gares are wide enough.
The spirit of gold instruct thee: hence all.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Fly.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Stay, lest you should want helpers at your calling
Any diuels shall come, (Search hound, Tobacco-spawling,
Vpshotten, Suckland, Glitterbacke, or any
Whom you shall neede to imploy, but call not many,
The'r's but few good in hell. And stay, remember
We all meete to heare how you prosper.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: The Tree
Blasted with Goblins, that about whose roote
5. Mandrakes growe, i'th Groue by Naples there,
Meete there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Wee shall.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Our blessings with you beare.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Dread king of Ghosts, weele plye our thrift so well,
Thou shalt be forc'd to enlarge thy Iayle of Hell.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Be quicke th'at best, let sawcy mortals know,
How ere they sleepe, there's one wakes here below.

div.stage: ¶ Enter Alphonso (King of Naples) Crownde, wearing Robes Imperiall, Swordes of State, Maces, &c. being borne before him, by Octauio Astolfo, (2. vnckles) Narcisso, Iouinelli, Brisco, (Counts) with others, Counte Spendola meeting them.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: One of those gallant Troupes went forth to meete
Your admirde Mistris (Erminhild the faire)
Hath left your Conuoy with her on the way.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And brings glad newes of her being here (this day)
Let Canons tell in Thunder her Arriuall,
When shee's at hand our selfe will meete her,

div.stage: Flourish Omn. On. Hee takes his Seate; Al kneele.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray rise; vntill about our browes were throwne,
These sparkling beames, such adoration
Was not bestowde on vs: whom does the knee
Thus louely worship? this Idoll, (Gold) or mee?
Indeed t'is the worlds Saynt, if that you adore,
Goe, pray to your coffers. None to vs shall bow,
Giue God your knees.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Whose owne voice does allow
That Subiects should to those who are Supreme,
Bend, as to God, (all Kings being like to him)

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Thou wonder of thy time, Ile pay no more
To thee of dutie than has bene before
And euer shall be payd to those sit Hye.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray mocke not mee with such Idolatry,
Kings, Gods are, (I confesse) but Gods of clay,
Brittle as you are, you as good as they,
Onely in weight they differ, (this poore dram)
Yet all but flesh and bloud; And such I am.
If such, pray let mee eate, drinke, speake, and walke,
Not look'd cleane through, with superstitious eyes,
(Not star'de at like a Comete.) As you goe
Or speake, or feede, (vnwondered at) let mee so.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Not Kings of Ceremonie.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Vncle what then?
Still are they Kings.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: But shew like common men.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Good vncle know, no Sunne in this our Spheare,
Shall rule but Wee, let others shine as cleare,
In goodnes, None in greatnes shall.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Blest raigne!
The Golden worlde is molding new againe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: All that I craue is this, and tis not newe,
Pay vnto Caesar onely Caesars due.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: We owe thee loyall hearts, and those weele pay,
Each minute (Mirrour of Kings.)

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Marke, the olde Lords promise their hearts, but no money.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here are the Names of bold conspirators,
(Yong Catilines, and farre more desperate)
Who in your Fathers dayes kindled the fires
Of here Rebellion.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Which are now burnt out.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Who knowes that? embers in dead Ashes lye.
King, Set thy hand to this let Traytors dye.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Tis fit you should doe so.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Sound Pollicie.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Men many things hold fit,
That are not good,
A yong Beginner and set vp in blood!
(Butchers can doe no more.)
Shall Recordes say
Being Crownde, he playd the Tyran the first day,
How should that Chronicler be curs'd? your paper.
When such a fatall booke comes in my sight,
Ile with Vespasian wish I could not write,
Their bond is canceld. I forgiue the debt,
See that at liberty, they all be set.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A Princely Act.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If wisely tis well done.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: That raigne must bost,
Which mercy has begun.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Beare witnes all, what pace the Chariot wheeles
Of our new guided Soueraigntie shall run.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: A mayne gallop I hope.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And here I vow to end as tis begun.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Heauen fill thee full of dayes,
But (being all told)
Ending no worse,
Their summe weele write in gold.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The course youle take deere Lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This: pray obserue it.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p: Call you this Coronation day? woud I were ith streetes where the conduites run claret wine, there's some good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Each weeke within the yeere shall be a booke
Which each day Ile reade or'e: I well may doe't,
The booke being but six leaues (six dayes,) the seuenth
Be his that owes it;
Sacred is that and hye;
And who prophanes one houre in that,
Shall dye.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: How manie wilbe left aliue then this day fortnight?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: First, beate all Tauernes downe then, Soules are lost
(Being drownde in Surfets) on that seuenth day most.
Stay (best of Kings) mine owne hand shall set downe
What lawes thou mad'st first day thou wor'st a Crowne.
Begin, begin thy weeke.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Write Monday.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: So so, Monday.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p: They say Monday's Shooemakers holliday, Ile fall to that trade.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I haue writ it downe my liege.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Peace, harken to your lesson.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: That day, from morne till night, Ile execute
The office of a Iudge, and wey out lawes
With euen scales.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Thats more than grocers doe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The poore and rich mans cause
Ile poize alike: It shall be my chiefe care
That bribes and wrangling be pitch'd o're the barre.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: We shall haue old breaking of neckes then.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Downe with that first.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O for a pen of gold!
Youle haue no bribes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yet terme-time all they yeere!
A good strong law, suite cannot now cost deere.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Haue you done?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I'me at bribes, and wrangling done presently.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: We must all turne pettifoggers, and in stead of gilt rapiers, hang buckram bags at our girdles.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: All my clients, shalbe women.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p: Because they are easiest fetched ouer: there's something to be gotten out of them.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Thy monday's taske is done: whats next?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Sunday if the weeke goes backward.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tuesdayes wee'le sit to heare the poore-mans cryes,
Orphans and widowes: our owne princely eyes
Shall their petitions reade: our progresse then
Shalbe to hospitalls which good minded men
Haue built to pious vse, for lame, sicks, and poore
Weele see whats giuen, what spent, and what flowes or'e
Churles (with Gods mony) shall not feast, swill wine,
And fat their rancke gutts whilest poore wretches pine.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: This is a braue world for beggers, if it hold.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Poore wretches pine, So are they left: tot'h next.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Wednesdaies weele spend.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: In fish dinners.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: In th' affaires
Of farren states, treate with embassadors,
Heare them and giue them answeres. Thursday, for warres.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p: That's well: better be together by th'eares, then to goe halting to hospitalls.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Our Neapolitane youths (that day) shall try
Their skill in armes, poore scorned Soldiers
Shall not be suffer'd beg here (as in some landes)
Nor stoope slaue-like to Captaines proud commands,
Starue, and lie nastie, when the selfe-same pay,
The Souldier fights for, keepes the Leaders gay.
Nor shall he through ice and fire make gray his bread,
Weare out new Moones, onely to earne his bread,
Wade vp to'th beard in torrents; and be drownd
All saue the head; march hard to meete a wound,
I'th very face, and euen his heart-strings cracke,
To win a towne, yet not to cloath his backe:
And the blacke storme of troubles being gon,
Shund like a creditor, not looked vpon,
But as court-pallats (when bright day drawes nye)
Rold vp in some darke corner is throwne by.
Vncle write that.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Fast as my pen can trot.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
What a number of tottred roagues wilbe turn'd into braue
fellowes a this new change of the moone

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: The brauer they are, the sooner are mercers vndon.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Souldiers are downe too.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Downe with Learning next.
For friday shalbe spent it'h reuerend Schooles,
Where weele sift branne from Houre, (hisse babling fooles,
But crowne the deepe-braind disputant) none shall hold
Three or foure Church-liuings (got by Symonious gold)
In them, to fat himselfe as in a stye,
When greater Schollers languish in beggery:
And in thin thred-bare cassacks weare out their age,
And bury their worth in some by vicorage:
This weele see mended.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Tyth pigges you'le smoake for this.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: So set it downe.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Schollers languish in beggery-So:
Thy fridaies law is writ; for Satterday, what?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I mary sir, All our cares now for that.
Well to begin, and not end so were base,
The winning of the gole crownes each mans race.

div.stage: Narcisso stepping in before in the Scene, Enters here.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Sir, theres a stranger newly ariu'de your court,
And much importunes to behold your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Of goodly presence.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: Let him see vs.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: The powers that guide me, guard thee, I haue heard thy name
In regions far hence, where it does resound
Lowder than here at home; to touch this ground
iha pass'd through countries, into which none here
Would willingly saile I thinke, and with me bring,
My loue and seruice, which to your grace I tender.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: What are you, and whence come you?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: From Heluetia.

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: What hell sayes hee?

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Peace you shall know hot hell time enough.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: I am an Heluetian borne, the house from which I am descended, ancient and well knowne to many princes: Bohor is my name.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Zounds! Bohor! has struck two of my teeth out with his name,

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A Shalcan Tartar being my grandfather
Men call me Shalkan Bohor. About the world
My trauailes make a girdle (perfect round:)
So that, what wonders Kings on earth euer found
I know, and what I know, Is yours.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Braue Heluetian,
We giue you thankes and welcome: your arriuall▪
Is faire and to our wish, of those dayes
Which Time sets downe, to number vp a weeke,
Euery day haue we tasked; saue onely one,
How in these courts of Kings (through which you haue gon,)
Doe Princes wast their howres?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: How but in that,
For which they are borne Kings? (Pleasure:) euery mans ayme,
Is to his pleasure: onely tis changde in name,
Thats all the difference; Are Kings Tirants? Blood
Is then their pleasure: thirst they after warres!
Ambition tickles them; that for which man most cares,
Good or bad, tis his pleasure, and to gaine it,
His soule must compasse it tho hell restraine it▪
To this marke all mens thoughts, Creation drew,
That all might striue for a thing, thats got by fewe:
Who are those few but Kings? and tis fit they
Should haue it, because true pleasure does soone decay.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How like you his counsell?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Rarely.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What ruffian's this?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bohor tha'st warm'd our yong blood; Al cares of state;
Shall that day sleepe, to our selfe weele Saterday haue,
Pleasure (the slaue of Kings shall then be our slaue,
Lords let there be a proclamation drawne,
What man soeuer (strange or natiue borne,)
Can feast our spleene, and heigthen our delight,
He shall haue gold and be our fauorite.
Tilts, turneys, masques, playes, dauncing, drinking deepe
Tho ere noone all Naples lye dead-drunke a sleepe.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: How King?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Weele haue it so vncle.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Downe with that too.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Print Satterday in great text letters.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Well, well, it shall.
Our swan turnes crow, poisond with one drop of gall.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Ile haue this proclamation forthwith drawne.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: And publish al the daies.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: And Satterday.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p: Especially that at large if you can in red, like a Dominicall letter.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Goe see it don.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: My taske.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why sigh you? Of six dayes wo'd you not spare me one?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Thine owne lawes from thine owne mouth, weele proclaime, if thine owne words thou e'arst, bee't thine owne shame.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Your long expected happines is arriu'd,
The princesse of Calabria.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou crown'st me agen▪
Deere vncle, honored Lords, with our whole court
Honor her hither; I am rapd with Ioy,
And lost till I behold her: fetch me my loue.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I feare deepe whirlepooles tho it run smooth aboue.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: To our worthy friend your welcomes.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: But pray Sir tell vs, meane you that we indeed
Shall haue but one playing day through the whole weeke?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: All Iouinells, weele be Iouiall all.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Till Satterday came, we liu'de in terrible feare.
Thanke Bohor, who your dead spirits vp did reare.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: Had I (as first I did begin) gon on,
I like a Schoole-boy should haue worne my crowne,
As if I had borrowed it.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Had bin most vile.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: Ile be a Sea, (boundles.)

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: Thou art a sunne,
And let no base cloudes muffle thee.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Braue Kings all!
Crowne, Scepter, Court, Cittie, Country, are at your call.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: There spake young loue indeede.

sp.speaker: Pris:
sp.l: The tyde now turnes.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: And now weele swim.

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: And laugh, tho the whole world mournes.

sp.speaker: Florish.
sp.l: Omn: Tantara, hey.

sp.speaker: Trumpets
sp.l: Erminghild brought in.

div.stage: Enter Octauio and Astolphe, vshering Erminhild, attended by Ladies and others.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Call vp your lustiest spirits: the Lady's come.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: O my earthly blisse! embraces! kisses! how sweete
Are you to parted Louers when they meete?
That entertainement which the Duke your Father,
Lent royellie (late to mee,) I now can pay
At a Kings charge: to our Neapolitane Court,
None (brightest Erminhild can come longd for
More then your selfe.) You haue stolne vpon vs (Ladie)

sp.speaker: Erm:
sp.l: You haue good Law against me, (playing the thiefe)
Your Grace may keepe mee prisoner.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: In these Armes;
From whence not Ioue shall raunsome thee; We Twaine
Will wed, and bed, and get a Prince shall raigne
In Naples brauely, when wee both lye dead:
Till then, Pleasures wings, to their full bredth be spread.

div.stage: Enter Scumbroth, ringing a Bell; Alphege, a Fryer, & Shackle-soule, in a Friers weede, with cloth to lay.

sp.speaker: Scum.
sp.p: A mangier, a mangier, a mangier, I must needs haue a mangie voice, when I doe nothing but ball for a company of hungry Scabs; a mangier.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.l: You must be nimble Rush.

sp.speaker: Sha:
sp.l: As a drawer in a new Tauern, first day the bush is hung vp.

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.l: A mangier, a manger, a mangier,

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: So: the Lord Priors napkin here, there the Subpriors: his knife and case of pick-toothes thus: as for the couent, let them licke their fingers in stead of wiping, and suck their teeth in steede of picking.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: What other dutie Sir, must I call mine?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: As you are nouice, you are to say grace demurely, waite on the Priors Trencher soberly, steale away a mouthfull cunningly, and munch it vp in a corner hungerly. Ply your office, Rush.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.l: Thankes good Frier Alphege: yes, Shackle-soule will play
The taske hee's set to: Diuels neuer idle lye:
Frier Rush! ha, ha: y'haue now an excellent quire,
To sing in hell, the Diuell and the Frier.

div.stage: Enter Prior, Subprior, Alphege, Hillary, Rush, and other Friers. All sit: dishes brought in before.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Where's Rush, our Iunior Nouice?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Here Lord Prior.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Stand foorth, and render thankes.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Hum, hum:
For our bread, wine, ale and beere,
For the piping hot meates heere:
For brothes of sundrie tasts and sort,
For beefe, veale, mutton, lamb, and porke.
Greene-sawce with calfes head and bacon,
Pig and goose, and cramd-vp capon.
For past raiz'd stiffe with curious art,
Pye, custard, florentine and tart.
Bak'd rumpes, fried kidneys, and lam-stones,
Fat sweete-breads, luscious maribones,
Artichoke, and oyster-pyes,
Butterd Crab, prawnes, lobsters thighes,
Thankes be giuen for flesh and fishes,
With this choice of tempting dishes:
To which proface: with bly the lookes sit yee,

sp.speaker: Rush.
sp.l: Bids this Couent, much good do't yee.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: How dar'st thou mock vs thou ill nurtur'd slaue?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Contemn'st thou our order and religious fare?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: He has spoken treason to all our stomaches.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Downe with the villaine.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Mischiefe on vs waites
If wee feede so vile a wretch.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thrust him out at gates.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I doe coniure you by my hallowed beades
To heare me speake.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Canst thou excuse thy selfe?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Alas (my Lord) I thought it had bin here
As in the neighbouring Churches, where the poor'st Vicar
Is filled vp to the chin with choice of meates,
Yet seekes new wayes to whet dull appetite,
As there with holy spels mens soules they cherish,
So with delitious fare, they themselues nourish.
Nor want they argument for sweete belly-cheere
To proue it lawfull.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Most prophane and fearefull.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: But since your order (pious and reuerend)
Tyed to religious fasts, spends the sad day
Wholy in meager contemplation,
I absolution beg on both my knees,
For what my tongue offended in: las! poore Rush
(See't by his cheekes) eates little: I can feede
On rootes, and drinke the water of the Spring
Out of mine owne cup: make an Anatomy
Of my most sinfull carcas: then pardon mee.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thy ignorance is thy pardon, wee beleeue thee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Gratias reuerenda domine Prior.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But do our brethren in parts more remote,
Feede so delitious saist thou?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Rush cannot lye.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou falsely doest accuse those holy men.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: How can it stand with their profession?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou saist (vile yongman) they haue arguments
To proue it lawfull gluttonously to feede.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Rush, answere the Sub-prior.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: Audite fratres, they doe not onely proue it lawfull, but make it palpable, that hee who eates not good in eate is dambde.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Benedicite.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: What shall become of all vs then?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou art distracted, whence canst thou force argument?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: From sillie reason, would you heare me speake?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Speake freely and be bold, listen.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: He that eats not good meate is dambd: Sie Dispute.
If he that feedes well hath a good soule, then è Contra.
No, he that feedes ill, hath a bad and a poore soule.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Thats wee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: And so consequenly is dambd, for who regards poore soules? and if they be not regarded they are cast foorth, and if cast foorth, then they are dambde.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I deny your minor, he that feedes well hath a good soule.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: Sic probo: the soule followes the temperature of the body, hee that feedes well hath a good temperature of body, Ergo, he that feedes well hath a good soule.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: A ful and edyfying argument.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I deny that the soule followes the temperature of the body.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: Anima sequitur temperaturam Corporis, It is a principle, & contra principia non est disputandum, All wee.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Its most apparent.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: O most learned Rush!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: A shallow Sophister, heare me farder.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Subprior, weele heare the rest disputed at our leisure: you take too much vpon you.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Shall I take this vpon me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Hence with this trash, we haue too long forborne to tast heauens blessings fully, which to our dutie had more enabled vs, Rush thart some Angel.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Rather some diuell sent to bewitch our soules.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Sub-prior no more.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I must speake, heare me brethren,
Shall we (bound by solemne oathes) t'abiure the world,
And all her sorceries▪ to whom night and day
Are as one hower of prayer? whose temperance makes vs
Endure what ful-fild bellie Gods admire;
Shall we (by zealous patrons) tyde to obserue
Dirges and Requiems for their peacefull soules,
In gluttonous riot bury sacred almes!
Turne Sanctimonious zeale and Charitie
To loathsome surfet? and those well-got goods
Our benefactors sau'd, by their owne fasts
And moderate liuing, shall we feede vpon
Ful-gorging vs till we vomit? fore-fend it heauen!
By all the Saints, by him first taught our order
What temperance was, here shall poore Clement feede,
Till his ore-wearied life, takes her last leaue
Of this all tempting world where all sinnes breede.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Howes this? are you become our confessor?
Best thrust vs out at gates, locke vp the Cloister,
And cal in whom you like: be you the Prior.
Speake are you agreed, Rush be our maister-cooke?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: You haue my voice.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Doe you all consent?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Yes, all.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: First send this fiend to banishment.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: We haue most voices on our side.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You may;
Las! most men couet still the broadest way.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Ciue Rush his charge then, Scumb: you must resigne.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: With a good maw, I shall haue a fatter office to be his scullion.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Worthy Lord Prior, heare me yet,
I must not my profession let,
To Scumbroath, what I know ile teach,
To make candels, Iellies, leach,
Sirrup of violets, and of roses,
Cow slip sallads, and kick-choses,
Preserue the apricock, and cherry,
Damsin-peare-plom, raspis berry;
Potates ike if you shall lack,
To corroborate the back:
A hundred more shall Rush deuice,
And yet to early mattins rise,
Our ladies office, sing at prime,
At euen-song, and at compline time.
Chant Anthems, Aniuersaries, Dirges,
And the dolefull de profundis.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou shalt not change thy order: Sirra, cooke,
From Rush take lessons against night, for fare
Abundance and delitious.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: I shall be greedy to learne of him sir, since your lordship is turnde, our very Iack and his spits shall turne too,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What men are these?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Welcome good holy father.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Thankes reuerend maister.

sp.speaker: 1, Pil.
sp.l: Blest sir, according to the Churches rite
We (Pilgrimes, to Ierusalem bound) this night
Desire repose, and pious charitie
In your most holy Couent.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: You are most welcome.
Alphege, goe lead'em in.

sp.speaker: Shas:
sp.l: By no meanes.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Tis mortall sin.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O black impietie!

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: How? sin to feed religious votaries!

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Rather to nourish idle vagabondes:
The Cleargy of other lands, haue with much plentie
And thrift destroyde those drones, that lazily
Liue eating vp the labours of the Bee.
A churchman there cares but to feede the soule,
He makes that charge his office. Al's misdeeds! alas!
They through the Lawyers hands are fitt'st to passe.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Can you heare this Diuell?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Besides my reuerend Lord,
These manderers here are spies, & soone beare word to Princes eares of what they heare and see.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Ha Rush! thou speak'st right.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Dambd iniquitie!

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Hence with those runnagates.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Come, hence.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Spurne 'em away.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Oh had mine eyes drop'd out ere seene this day.
Stay comfortles poore soules, my pittying teares
Shall speake what my tongue dares not, here holy men,
You nere shall say when next we meete againe,
Frier Clement to the hungrie grutch'd his meate,
Or to the weary pilgrim lodging, this makes you eate,
And when you haue relieu'd your fainting limbes,
Commend me in your prayers, and midst your hymmes
Thus wish, that he who did your Iorney furder,
May neuer liue, to breake his holy order.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Old superstitious dotard; beate hence these beggers.

sp.speaker: 1. Pil.
sp.l: Many old mens curses will on his soule be spent,
Who thus defaces, Charities monument:

sp.speaker: Shal
sp.p: I told you they were curs, that cease to barke, no longer then you feede them.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Frier thou speak'st right:
Make hast with fare delitious, weele crowne the night.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Ha ha, laugh Lucifer, dance grim fiends of hell,
Of soules thou iudge must, but most terrible,
I must exact a double pay from thee,
Nere hadst thou Iorney man deserude such fee,
Let me cast vp my reckonings, what I ha won
In this first voiage: Charity! shees vndon:
Fat gluttony broke her back: next her step'd in
Contention (who shakes Churches) now the sweete sin
(Sallow lechery,) should march after: Auarice,
Murder, and all sinnes els, hell can deuice,
Ile broach: the head's in, draw the body after,
Begin thy feast in full cuppes, end in slaughter
That damnedst fury: oh, but Frier Clement's free!
True: ha'st no snare t' intrap him let me see.
Hees old, choake him with gold; hold on thy Reuells,
Pluto makes Sackle-soule president of Diuels.

div.stage: Enter K. Octauio, Narcisso, Iouinelli, Spendola.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What pictar's that (Vncle Octauio?)

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The picture of thy state, (drawne by thy selfe,)
This is that booke of statutes, were enacted
In the high Parliament of thy roiall thoughts
Where wisedome was the speaker. And because
Thy subiects shall not be abusde by lawes
Wrap'd vp in caracters, crabbed and vnknowne,
These thine owne language speake.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hang 'em vp vncle.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What sayes the King?

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.l: You must hang vp the lawes.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Like cob-webbe in fowle roomes, through which great flies
Breake through, the lesse being caught byth wing, there dies.
No no, thy lawes Ile fix full in thy sight, Hangs a table vp.
(Like sea-markes,) that if this great ship of sway
And kingly ventures, loose her constant way.
Ith bottomles gulph of state, (beaten by the stormes
Of youthfull follie, raging in monstrous formes)
Shee may be sau'de from sinking and from wrack,
(Steerd by this compasse, for the points of it
Shall guide her so, on rockes she cannot split.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You are our carefull pilot in this voiage
Of Gouernment, be you our Admirall.
Wisedome and Age being props, realmes seldome fall.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Oraculous is thy voice.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: How now count Brisco?
Me thinkes I read a comedy in thy lookes.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Has met some merry painter, hees drawne so liuely.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Come count your newes.

sp.speaker: Bris:
sp.l: I shall bestow them freely:
The physicke of your proclamation workes:
Your guilded pills (roll'd vp in promises
Of princely fauours to his wit, who highest
Can raise your pleasures) slip so smoothly downe
Your Subiects throates, that all (vpon a sudden)
Are loosely giuen.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: How? loosely giuen? why count?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Name but what sport, your Highnes would haue Acted
I'me prologue too●: your court must haue more gates
To let in rufling Saterday: without (now) waites
Musicke in some ten languages: each one sweares
(By Orpheus fiddle-case) they will tickle your eares
If they can doo't with scraping.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: Theres seuen score Noise at least of english fidlers.

sp.speaker: Io:
sp.l: 7. score! they are able to eate vp a citie in very scraps

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.p: Very base-viall men most of 'em: besides whole swarmes of welsh harpes, Irish bag-pipes, Iewes trompes,
sp.l: And french kitts. All these made I together play:
But their dambd catter-wralling, frighted me away.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: These sports to please
A Princes eyes?

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: How like you then of these?
The cittie-waterbearers (trimly dight)
With yellow oaker-tankerds (pind vpright)
Like brooches in their hatts; In their fresh loues
A may-game bring, All, wearing dog-skin gloues.
Made not to shrinke it'h wetting.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Bid these poore men drinke well, and so be gon.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What will you haue then?
Will you see the Turners shew, brauely preparde
With colours, drumes, and gunnes (with rust halfe mar'de
Bearing that, of which they long haue bin depriu'de.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What ist?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Their daring Giant, (newly reui'de)

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: For Ioues sake lets see that.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O fie (Prince) fie!
In thy court painted monsters, they come not here,
Ride forth, thou shalt meete Giants euery where.
Me thinkes (yong Lords) your soules being new refinde
With beames of honor, should not be declin'de
To sports so low and vulgar: but since the King
Of birdes (the Eagle) letts you spred a wing
So neere his owne, you should put vp such game
As fits an Eagle, and pursue the same.
And not like rauens, kites, or painted Iayes
So'are high, yet light on dunghills, for stinking preyes.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Old Lord you raue.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: What sports wood you deuise?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Most fit for Kings. Were I (before his eyes)
To present obiects, they should all be rare,
Of Romane triumps, laden with the spoiles of warre:
Or Lions, and wilde-Beares kill'd by actiue force:
Or sea-fights: or land battailes on foote, or horse:
Such sights as these, kindle in Kings braue fire,
And meeting spirits that dare mount, mount'em higher,
Where apish pastimes lay our soules downe flat,
Groueling on earth, base and effemminate.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I haue bowles of this bias too, for your Lordships alley.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Trundle'em out before him.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: The wodden-leg Souldier,
Waites to present you with his show of warre.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I mary my liege.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: The Scholler has his deuice, the Mariner his.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: These are Kings sports indeed.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Will you see these?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Faith be it so; because weele now rather please
Our vncle than our selfe, pray fetch in these.
The rest cashere.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Send the fidlers merily home.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: And yet pa'em scuruily! tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: And bid the water-bearers clense the citie
Ther's many a foule thing in it.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Marshall 'em in.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: Ile fetch these worthy spirits in my selfe.
No, no, weele ayde you sir.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: March: and giue vs roome.

sp.speaker: Ki:
sp.l: Sdeath! if these doting gray-beards might haue their wills,
We neuer shall haue ours: let vs crosse them
As they crosse vs.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: How, how!

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: Euery deuice
Their Ningles bring in, abuse with scuruie iest,
Beet nee're so good.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: If Ninies bring away the Nest.

sp.speaker: Ki:
sp.l: Teach Iouinelli and Brisco when to giue fire.
Dromes and trompets sounding,

div.stage: Enter Octauio, Iouinelli, Brisco, Rufman, the Souldier, Scholler, Mariner.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I am a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: We know that by your legges.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Does my stump grieue you?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Not if you bestir your slu●panimbly sir.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: What hot shot's this?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: A Souldier sir: thats all:
Thats more than sir I thinke you dare be Zounds! baffuld
For my limbes lost in seruice! your noble father
Has clapd this buff-ierkin, when this Stump of wood
Has vp to th' 'knee stucke three howres in french blood:
When such as you, with your Spangled roses, that day
Brauely bestird their 〈◊〉, and ran away:
Ile stand toot, I.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: With one leg.

sp.speaker: Sol:
sp.l: Yes: with one.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Yong Lords, thus to scorne Souldiers, tis ill don.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Vncle, heres no man scornes'em; must we be brau'de
By a staring fellow, for a little fighting? goe.

sp.speaker: Sol:
sp.l: Fighting! I cannot halt I, but speake plaine,
No King on earth baffalls me, ide baffall againe,
Th' whole race of great turkes, had iem ith field: I ha brought
With me a hundred Souldiers, (old Seruitors)
Poore as my selfe in clothes; picke out fiue hundred
Of such silke-stocken men, if they beate vs, hang vs,
S'bloud if we tosse not them, hang's agen: a fort
We ha built without, and mand it, this was the sport
A Souldier wood ha giuen thee: my one hundred
Had taught thee all the rules i'th Schoole of warre.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: All this ile read without may me, wound or scarre.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: What say you to an Engine, that at once
Shall spoile some thirtie men?

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Thirtie men! nothing.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: If nothing! hast thou bin beate for this? farewell.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: I can fetch twenty fortueners haue don more
With a bare goose-quill.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Maist thou but liue, to need a Souldiers arme,
That laught to see him bleed.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: You haue lost the day sir, for your Souldiers fly.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Fly to the diuell let'em.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Your leaders before.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: You fight all vnder one cullors? doe you not?

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Sir: these pleasures to the King which I prefer,
Flow from Ioues braine.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Heyda! heres one has beaten out Ioues braines.

sp.speaker: Seap.
sp.l: Wud I had thee hung vp at our maine kit.

sp.speaker: Sch:
sp.l: No Sir Ioues braine, (Minerua queene of wit)
If all the Muses and the Arts can fit
With their high Tunes, such choice and Princely eares,
Apollo (Father to them all)— appeares—

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.p: Apollo was an Asse; he let a wench whom he lou'de to be turnd into a Bay-tree, and now shees glad for a peny to stick Ale-house-windowes, and wynde dead coarses.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Let Apollo goe and lye with his owne Daughters.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Are you a Scholler Syr?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p: A school-master as I take it; and comes to present a verie prettie show of his schollers in broken Latin.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Can wee be dumb and see this?

sp.speaker: Sch:
sp.l: O haples Learning!
Flie and complaine, to Heauen (where thou wert borne)
That thou (whome Kings once nursde,) art now their scorne.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: How blowes the winde Syr?

sp.speaker: Seaf:
sp.l: Wynde! is Nore-Nore-West.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: To hoyse your sayles vp too, I thinke tis best.

sp.speaker: Sea:
sp.p: A blacke Gust is comming: vp a low-there hey: A young-man vp toth Top-mast-head, and looke-out: stand to your Sayles: stand to your Top-sailes: let goe your Harriars, let goe, amaine louere amaine, quicke, quick, Goodfellowes.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.p: Hees mad.

sp.speaker: Sea:
sp.p: Whoes at Helme? beare vp hard: and hard vp: and thou beest a man beare vp; Star-borde, Port-agein: off with your Drablers, and your Banners; our with your Courses: Ho,— I spie two Shippes yonder, that yaw too and agen, they haue both sprung a Leake, I thinke the Diuell is sucking Tabaccho, heeres such a Mist: out with your boate, and you Besmen, cut-downe Maste-bith-borde; beare vp,
sp.l: Ime a Blunt-fellow you see, All I say is this,
You that scorne 〈…〉, shall a Sea-man misse.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Now by my life I haue patient stood too long.
To see rich merit and loue, payde with base wrong:
Learning! and Armes! and Traffique! the triple wall
That fortifies a Kingdome, race em downe All!
This Seaman, (hee that dearest earnes his bread)
Had rigd and mann'd 4 Gallies brauely furnisht,
With Souldiers, Rowers, and Fire-workes for a Sea-fight.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You are full of Squibs too, pray goe fire em all.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Must I bee then cashierde too? mary and shall.
To saue thy sinking Honour, Ile send hence
These men with thankes, with praise, and recompence.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Pray doe.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Braue Shalcan-Bohor, all this while
Our eye has followed yours, and seene it smile,
(As twere in scorne) of what these men could doe,
Which made vs slight them off; to ingrosse you
(Our best and richest prize:) ith Courts of Kings
Through which you ha passd, you ha seene wonders, shew em.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: I shall at opportune howers. If your Grace
Arride the toyes, they bragd of (Fire-workes,
And such light-stuffes) Sit fearelesse without danger
Of murdring shot, which villaines might discharge
In (idle counterfet Sea-fights) you shall see
At opening of this hand, a thousand Balles
Of wilde-Fire, flying round about the Aire— there.
Fire-workes on Lines.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Rare, Rare.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Tis excellent S'death from whence flew they?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Hell, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Hell! Nay, if any that are in Hell, skip vp euer so nye Heauen, as these Diuells that spit fire did, Ile drinke nothing but Gun-pouder.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Ha, ha, a trifle this. Your Scholler there,
Come with his Arts and Muses shallow, leaden braine,
Your swaggering Souldier, lead a tottered traine
Of ruffianly Boote-hallers: I noted all
These feasts for Kings: ith garden of varietie
The vast world! you are staru'de midst your satietie,
Plucke no one Apple from the golden Tree,
But shake the fruite of euery pleasure downe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thanks Bohor; why else weares a King his Crowne?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Shalcan, all Naples shall not buy thee from mee.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Nor you and these from me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Aske what thou wilt haue
But to stay here.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Loe, this is all I craue.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou hast our fast embraces.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Swift as mans thought,
Various delights shall bee each minute borne,
And dye as fast that fresh may rise; wee scorne
To serue vp one dish twice; bee't nere so rare,
Will you that gainst to morrow I prepare
A Feast of strange Mirth for you?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Deare Bohor doe.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: I shall; Nor doe I thus your loue pursue,
With seruile hopes of Golde, I neede it not:
If out the jawes of Hell Golde may bee got
Blacke Artes are mine to doo't; and what delights
Those worke bee yours.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou art gratious in our sight.
sp.stage: ¶ A Table is set out by young fellowes like Merchants men, Bookes of Accounts vpon it, small Deskes to write vpon, they sit downe to write Tickets, Lurchall with them.
sp.l: 1 Come fellow Lurchall write.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fuh, Stay not for mee,
I shall out-goe you all.
2 I hold 5. Crownes,
Wee all leaue you behinde vs.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Don; but I
sp.p: Must not leaue you behinde mee; what paines a poore Diuell takes to get into a Merchant? hees so ciuill,
sp.l: One of Hell must not know him, with more ease
A Diuell may win ten Gallants, then one of these,
Yet a Merchants wife, before these ten is wonne
To entertaine her Diuell, if Pride be one.
But Lurchall, now tha'rt in, and for yeares bound,
To play the Merchant, play him right: th'ast found
A Master, who more villenie has by hart,
Then thou by rote; See him but play his owne part,
And thou doest Hell good seruice; Barteruile,
Theres in thy name a Haruest makes mee smile.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Lurchall:— within

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: My master calls.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I.
sp.stage: Men too and fro bring in Bags, & haue Bills.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: Oh, art there?
This day twixt one and two a Gallants bound
To pay 400. Crownes to free his Landes
Fast morgag'de to mee, Lurchall, got thee vp hye
Into my Turret, where thou mayest espie
All commers euery way; if by thy guesse,
Thou seest the Gull make hither.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So Syr.

sp.speaker: Barr.
sp.l: That, his Hower
Lye gasping, at the last Minutes; let him beate at dore,
Within Ile beate his heart out.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Ile let him stand.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: Do, take my Watch, go faster. All his Land
Is sumd with these two Figures, (2. and 1.)
At past one, (his,) strike but two, tis mine owne.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Ile turne the wheeles: and spin the howers vp faster

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: The Citie-clockes then strike, and kill thy Master.
Would all the Citie-Sextons, at my cost
Were drunke this day 4. howres.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Troth so wud I,
And wee their Iackesath Clocke-house.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Wee'de strike merily.
Fly vp to'th topath house,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: There sir, Ile sit,
And croake like a Rauen, to damb thee in hels pit.

div.stage: Barteruile set amongst his men reading a long scroll.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How goes this moneth?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Much shorter than the last.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Weddings this moneth 12. thousand: not worth the scoring,
But thinke ther's little marying, we ha so much whoring.
Grynding milles so much-vsde; about the citie
Such grinding, yet no more mony; suites in law,
Full brought to an end this moneth, no more but ten:
This law will begger vs: had I the bags againe,
I bought this combrous office with, the King
Should make his best of't: hee that did farm't before
Had it for lesse than I, yet receiude more.
How much remaines of the salt tribute due?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: 7000. Crownes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thats well: a sauorie summe:
These our Italian tributes, were well deuisde,
Me thinkes tis fit a subiect should not eate
But that his Prince from euery dish of meate
Should receiue nourishment: for (being the head)
Why should he pine, when all the body is fed?
Besides, it make vs more to awe a King,
When at each bit we are forc'd to thinke on him.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: What payment's this?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: The pension of the Stewes, you neede not vntye it, I brought it but now from the sealers office: ther's not a peece there, but has a hole in't, because men may knowe where twas had, and where it will be taken againe: blesse your worship? Stew-mony sir, Stew-Prunc cash sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They are sure, tho not the soundest pay maisters,
Read whats the summe.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: But bare 200. crownes.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: They are bare crownes indeede sir, and they came from Animals and vermin that are more bare: wee that are clarkes of these flesh-markets haue a great deale of rotten mutton lying vpon our hands, and finde this to bee a sore payment.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well, well, the world will mend.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So our surgeons tell'em euery day; but the pox of mendment I see.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Doe not your gallants come off roundly then?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Yes sir, their haire comes off fast enough, we turne away crack't french crownes euery day. I haue a suite to your worship in behalfe of all our dealers in small wares, our freewhores sir, you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If your whores are knowne, whats thy suite?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I should haue brought a petition from 'em, but that tis put off sir, till clensing-weeke, that they may all be able to set to their hands, or else a whores marke.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well, well, whats their request?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Mary sir, that all the shee-tobacco-shops, that creepe vp daily in euery hole about the Citie, may bee put to scilence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why pray thee honest fellow?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I thanke your good worship, I had not such a sweete bit giuen me this 7 yeeres, honest fellow: marry sir Ile open to you your suppliants cases: they that had wont to spend a crowne about a smocke, haue now their delight dog-cheape, but for spending one quarter of that mony in smoake: besides sir, they are not contented to robbe vs of our customes only, but when their pipes are fowle with spitting and driueling in those foresaide shops, they haue no place to burne 'em in, but our houses.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Draw their petition, and weele see all cur'de.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Let a frost come first sir: I thanke your venerable worship; the pox gnaw out so many small guts as haue payde thee crownes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The tyd's against you sir, the crownes are come.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How goes my watch?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: As most watches vse to goe sir, sleepily, heauily.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Not reach'd to one yet; wert thou to be hangd,
The hower had gallop'd.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I spurd it all that I could.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: S'death keek his howre, heauen helpe poore Citizens,
If Gentlemen grow thus warie: let him in.
Barren now, that hast in craft so fruitfull bin.
Your businesse sir to me.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Doe you not know me sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No in good truth sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent:
sp.l: To know you I am bold sir,
You haue lands of mine in morgage, this is my day,
And heres your crownes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Signior Innocentio;
My memorie had quite lost you, pray sit both,
A bowle of wine here.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Sir it shall not neede:
Please you to fetch my euidence, whil'st we tell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What needes this forward spring? faith two moneths hence
Had bin to me as welcome.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Sir I thanke you.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Your hower drawes on Signior Innocentio,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Goe beate a drumme ith garret, that no tongues
Of clockes be heard but mine.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Little past one.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Winde, winde.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thus wind'st thou to damnation.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Ile part with none sir, pardon me, till I see
Your writings: will you fetch the euidence sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What euidence sir, haue I of yours?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: My friend sir, whose mony hee lends me to redeeme my morgage.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Which you would haue for your securitie.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Tis so sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No sir Innocentio, To morrow on your bare word will I lend you 30. crownes more: I loue you sir, and wish you beware whose hands you fall into: the worlds a serpent.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: This does but spend the hower sir, will you take your mony?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Let him see my writings then.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Haue you such couenant from mee? I remember none.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Your conscience is sufficient couenant sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ha! whats that conscience? I know no law-termes I,
Talke to me as to Citizen.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Weele dally no longer;
We knew what snake would sting vs, and therefore brought
Our medcine gainst his venome: youle keepe the writings,
And weele ith Court of conscience tender your crownes,
Whither this writ does summon you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A fox, and ore-taken?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Serue writs vpon me, yet keepe my mony too?
Dull slaue hast thou no braine?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Braine! trye this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Will you as fits a Christian giue vs in
What is our right, and take your crownes sir yet?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Tis good to try mens patience, fetch me downe
Those writing on my pillow, there they ha slept
These two howers for you: must not friends iest? ha!

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Yes sir: let your men tell, iust 400. crownes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Besides the vse.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: The vse is there too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Hold: Ile take it without telling, put it vp.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Not till we see the writings.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Dare you touch it?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Dare! yea sir, and dare stab him to the heart,
Offers to take it from vs:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who stabs first? Flings mony amongst it.
Now touch it if you dare: ther's gold of mine,
And if they lay one finger on't, cry theeues,
They come to rob me, touch it if you dare.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Dambde wretch, thou wilt goe quicke to hell I feare.

sp.speaker: Aur
sp.l: No sir, the diuell shall fetch me when I goe.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That all my errand.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: We are cheated both.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Proceede, in your chancery suite, I haue begun your bill.
Humbly complayning.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Of thee villaine He complaine
That sels thy soule for mony, diuels on earth dwell,
And men are no where, all this world is hell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I kisse thy forhead, my wittie Oedipus
That canst vnfold such riddels: one ringes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound
To doe you all seruice, till I you all confound.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Maister Siluerpen the procter sir, sends word, if you come not in to morrow and personally depose your payment of the 200. crownes, youle be non-suited.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That is a law-draught goes downe coldly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why sir? Tis but your swearing the mony is payde.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: If oathes had back-dores to come in at, without danger of damnation, to catch a mans soule byth back, swearing were braue.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: What answere shall I giue the Proctors man?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Tell him my maister shall come in and sweare.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Doe, tell him: on thee Ile build: now all my feare,
Is for apparance at the Chancellors Court,
No trick to saue that?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I haue a braue one fort.
Bring in a pottle of wine: will Carlo here my fellow,
Depose a truth if he see it, to helpe his maister?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What thou not honest Carlo?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Here's the wine.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Set this to your head anon sir, when tis there
Away you, and to morrow thou mai'st sweare
Before the Chancelor, and sweare true, if hee
Were in that case thou leftst him, twere in vaine
To hope he could liue, till thou camst back againe.
All Knights a'th Post learne this trick: the fits vpon me now.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Take a good draught, twill helpe you sir: It gulpes, hees almost breathles Carolo; away.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am gon.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Hees gon, hees gon sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: One gulpe more had choaked me;
This wine had washed my feares off, tha'st giuen mee power
To make me doate vpon thee. Carolos gon.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes and will sweare his heart out, to your good.
Sweare let him; bee thy selfe and hee dambde too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So I may get by it. In my bosome sleepe
(My doue, my loue,) prosper but thou and I,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And let all els sinck.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let'em: so I kisse gold,
The yongmans whore, the saint of him that sold.

div.stage: Enter Prior, Alphege Hillary, and Friers with pruning kniues, spades, &c. met by Subprior, and Shackle-soule.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Whither (mad-men) run you?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: To our Vines.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Your Vines?
(The tree of sin and shame?) this Serpent here,
Has with that liquorish poison, so set on fire
The braines of Nicodeme and Siluester,
That they in drunken rage haue stabd each other.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Stabd!

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Yes, they bleede a little, but haue no harme,
Their yong blood with the grapes Iuice being made (warme,
They brawld and struck, but I kept off the blowes,
Yet the Subprior saies from me their quarrell rose.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: It did.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: In very deede (for I not sweare)
It did not sir: to me you malice beare,
As if that all such mischife don, were mine,
But cause your selfe shall see how I repine
To see vice prosper, pardon me good Lord Prior▪
If I a tell-tale be of what mine eyes
Beheld with water in them: sin will rise
In holy sircles I see sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: What sin?

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: What hast thou seene?

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Wud present I had not beene,
But till I vtter it, my clogd conscience beares▪
A man vpon a woman.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: I speak't in teares:
Scumbroth our cooke, and a female I beheld
Kissing in our orchard: on her lippes he dwelld
I thinke some halfe howre.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Shame to our reuerend order!
A woman in our couent! Sin black as murder.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: Our cooke shalbe seuerely punished: a woman,
A tempter here.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Abhominable!
Rush, thoul't rebuke sin.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Tho my Lord I'me bad, I'me not giuen that way.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.l: Let vs some plagues inuent to lay on this lecherous knaue.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Some light punishment
(Good my Lord Prior) suppose twere your owne fault,
Whip as you woud be whipd, the best's naught.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: He shalbe punisht, and then loose his place.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: That sir shall be as we will: to our Vines: away.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: For shame giue or'e, dare you prophane this day
That is to holy vses consecrate?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Why? what day is this?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Lambert the marter.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: No matter,
To vex thee deeper, this whole day weele spend,
Onely about our Vines.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You vex not me,
But heauen: what warrants you to this?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Our will.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou hast thy will, thy wish thou ne're shalt haue,
In sight of heauen who sees and punishes
Mens blacke impieties; And in sight of these
(Sharers in thy full sin:) And in his sight,
T' expresse whose vilenes, there's no epithite.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: No matter what he saies Rush.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I'me knowne what I am.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: To thee I prophecie, (vitious old man to thee,
Who er'st with lift-vp-hands, and downe-bowed knee,
Seemest to' haue had worke in heauen: now (full of spite,
Onely to eate a liquorish appetite;
Digst our religious wales vp, planting there
Luxurious fruits to pamper belly-cheere▪
(For all thy paines to dresse it,) of this Vine
Thy lustfull lips shall neuer tast the wine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Distracted foole, in stead of my iust anger,
Thou onely hast my pittie: thou prophecie?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Laugh on, but since nor prayers preuaile not teares,
Ile powre my griefe into my Princes cares.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Heele goe and complaine to the King.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Let him complaine,
Kings cannot Subiects of their foode restraine,
Away.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Ingender sin with sin; that wines rich heate
May bring forth Lust, Lust murder may beget,
But here strike saile, this barke awhile hale in,
And lanch into the deepe, a brighter sin:
Ho, Glitterbacke, ascend, to shackle-soule,
To shackle-soule ascend, ho Glitterbacke;
Thou richest spirit, thrust vp thy golden head
From hell thus hie: when? art imprisoned
In misers chests so fast thou canst not come?
Or fearst thou theeues, or cutpurses? here be some
Can saue thee from their fingers: when? Arise;
And dazle th' approching night with thy glistring eyes.

sp.speaker: Glitt:
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: How thou sweatst with comming? Saue me those drops
(Golds pure Elipar) stilling from thy lockes:
Shake from thy browes and hayre that golden showre,
So: get home: quicke: (to hell) least hell grow poore,
If Richmens pawes once fasten thee, and beware
It'n way thou meetst no Lawyers: theile pull thee bare,
Hence: downe.

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: I me gon.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Coole night will call Frier Clement forth anon:
Angels, be you his strong temptation:
Wines lustfull fires him warme not: At this spring,
(Scornde by the rest for him,) spred thy gilt wing,
Full in his eye; As he drinks water downe
In streames of Auarice, let his weake soule drowne.

div.stage: Enter the King, Narcisco, Brisco, Spendola, Iouinelli, Rufman, followed by Astolfo.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I doe beseech your Highnes, yet turne backe
And comfort the sad Lady, whose faire eyes
Are worne away with weeping.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: If her eyes be worne away, what should a man doe
With a blind wife? kill her with flyes?

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: I cannot abide a woman thats fond of me.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: I would loue a woman but as I loue a walnut, to cracke
It, and peele it, eate the meate, and then throw away the Shell.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.p: Or as noble-men vse their great horses, when they Are past seruice: sell'em to brewers and make'em drey-horses: So vse a woman.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: So so.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: The Indians are warme without clothes, and a man Is best at ease without a woman: or if your Highnes must 〈…〉 haue one, haue factors to buy the fairest, doate not any, 〈…〉 the turke, regard none, yet keepe many. 〈…〉 You heare the Iuries verdit. 〈…〉 whose foreman's the diuell? 〈…〉 counsell thee to thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Destruction? why? the heauen can abide but one sun,
I hope we on earth may loue many mens daughters▪
Tell Erminhilda so: send her home to the duke her father:
And tell him too, because the disease of mariage
Brings the stone with it, I hate a woman; I loue not
To be cut: inclosde grounds are too rancke.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Best feeding on the Commons then.
Will you not mary this chast Lady then?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: No sir, and will you now my reason haue?
A womans is an insatiate graue.
Wherein hee's dambd that lyes buried.

sp.speaker: Our
sp.l: On, on, away.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Braue battailes I fight you, but ile win the day.

div.stage: Manet, Astolpho, Enter Octauio and Ermynhilda.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I heard the storie, tell't not or'e againe,
Twere crueltie to wound men, being halfe slaine.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Tis crueltie too much, and too much shame
That one of your high birth, youth, beautie, name,
And vertues shining bright, should hence be sent
(Like some offender into banishment)
Abusde by a King, and his luxurious traine,
Of parasites, knaues, & fooles, (a kingdomes bane,)
For them, by him not carde for; you came not so,
But as his bride, his Queene, and bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: And yet am neither, from my fathers court
Came I (being sude by Princes too) for this?
To see him, his subiects scorne, and my selfe his?
Once thought I that his loue had bin (as fate)
Vnmoueable; and ist now turn'd to hate?
Yes, yes, hees wauering as the running streame,
And far more ydle than a mad-mans dreame.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Send to the duke your father, let him inforce
Your plighted mariage.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Worse than a diuorce
No: to his eyes since hatefull I am growne,
Ile leaue his Court and him, and dye vnknowne.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: All runnes I see to ruine.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If he persue,
These godles courses, best we leaue him too,
That land to it selfe must a quick downefull bring,
Whose King has lost all, but the name of King.

div.stage: Enter Subprior with an earthen pot, and a lanthorne; Scumbroath with him with a peice.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Get thee to bed thou foolish man and sleepe.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: How? Sleepe? no sir no, I am turnd a tyrant and cannot sleepe:
sp.l: I stand centinell perdu, and somebody dyes if I sleepe,
I am possest with the diuell and cannot sleepe.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What diuell possesses thee?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: The fencers diuell▪ a fighting diuell; Rush has committed a murder vpon my body, and his carcas shall answere it; the cock of my reuenge is vp.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Murder! what murder?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: He has taken away my good name, which is flat manslaughter, and halfe hangd me, which is as much as murder, he told the Lord Prior and you that I was kissing a wench: Its a lye, I giue him the lye, and he shall fight with me at single pistall against my caliuer, do I looke like a whoremonger? when haue you seene a wencher thus Diary as I am: Rush thou diest for this treason against my members concupiscentiallitie.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou wut not kill him, wut thou?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: No, but Ile make him know what tis to boile a cooke in's owne grease.

I am scalding hot; I am chargd with furie, I carie a heart-burning within me. I kisse a whore? I shall haue boyes cry out to me, now who kist Mary? No Rush, Scumbroth shall giue thee suger pellets to eate, I will not be danc'de vpon.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Let me perswade thy peace of minde to night,
Get thee to rest, if Rush haue thee belide,
Reioyce, by wrongs to haue thy patience tride.
He shall forgiuenes aske thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Let me but haue one blow ats head with my cleauer Ith kitchin, and I freely forgiue him, or let me bownce at him.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: These bloudie thoughts will dam thee into hell.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Doe you thinke so? what becomes of our roaring boyes then that stab healths one to another, doe you thinke they will be dambd vp too?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I thinke so, for I know it, deere sonne to prayer,
Two sinnes beset thee, murder, and despaire,
I charge thee meete me at my cell anon,
To saue thee will I spend my orison.
In name of heauen I charge thee to be gon.

sp.speaker: Suc.
sp.p: Well sir▪ the cold water of your counsell has laid the neate of my furie: he had met with his match, but I wil shoote off my anger, I will be gon, and why? Looke you, because the moone is vp and makes hornes at one of vs; As the noblemans coach is drawne by foure horses, the knights by two, & the cuckold by three, euen so am I drawne away with none at all. Vale, Bonos Noches: I am possest still: It buzzes, here. Vale.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Blest star of light, stucke there to illuminate
This world darkned or'e with sin: thou watchest late,
To guide mans comming home, shewing thereby
Heauens care of vs, seeing how we tread awry
We haue two great lights for midnight and for noon,
Because blacke deeds at no time should be don.
All haile to thee (now my best guide) be giuen,
What needs I earths candle, hauing the lamp of heauen?
Now Benedicite? where am I?

sp.speaker: Rush.
sp.l: O whether am I going? which way came I?
Ah wellada, I come to fill my pot,
With water not with thee; thou art misbegot.
Else wouldst thou not lye there; what Orphans blood
Hast thou suckt out, to make this golden flood?
None drinke this well but I, how is it than
Thou thus way-lay'st me, (theefe to the soule of man?
Would some poore wretch (by losse of law vndone)
Had thee: goe doe him good: me canst thou none.
My wholesome cup is poysond, it flowes or'e
With mans damnation (gold,) drinke there no more

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Not tast what all men thirst for? old and so braue,
When mony assaults, one combat more Ile haue.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: So, ho, ho, father, Subprior.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Whoes there? what art thou callst me?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: One that feeds the hungry, the cooke sir, Scumbroth.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Come hither, I haue for thee a golden prize.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Ha ha: heele take it.
Villaines and fooles will ha gold, (tho got from hell,)
But they who doe so, (as thou shalt) pay for't well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: But stay, father Subprior, before we goe one step farder, what doe you thinke I haue done since I went from you?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No hurt I hope, say hast thou?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Hurt? If I did hurt in that, how much harme doe Almanake makers, who lye coldly quiuering at it all the yeare long? I did doe nothing but stand staring at the man in the moone.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And what good thoughts bred that within thee?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: This: I thought to my selfe, what a happy fellow that man in the moone was, to see so many fooles and knaues here below, and yet neuer to be troubled with 'em, nor meddle with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Hees happy that meddles not with this world indeed.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: If that man in the moone should write a prognostication, oh he should not neede to tell astronomicall lyes to fill his booke, nor talke in gibrish no man vnderstands, of Quartiles, Aspects, Stations, Retrogradations, Peragrations; Centricall, Eccentricall, Cosmicall, Acronicall, and such Palquaicall, Solar, Lunar, Lunaticall vaulting ouer the railes of heauen, that no Christian dare looke vpon their tricks, for feare his wit breake his necke.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou putst into a Sea, thou canst not sound,
Ignorance still is foe to Arts profound.
Come hither man, come hither.

sp.speaker: Scu.
