sp.p: Arts profound, Arts make men as very asses as women doe, I haue no Art, and yet I knowe this Moone that shines to night, sees more than you or I doe, for all your spectacles.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: True, tis the eye of heauen.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Which of the eyes? tis but the left eye: and the Sun is the right: and yet the left sometimes sees more than the right, and the right as much as the left, there's paxonisme for you father globicall paxonisme.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I vnderstand thee not.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: No, why heres the oyster opend, I say the Sun sees much knauery in a yere, & the Moone more in a quarter▪ the Moone sees men caryed by a quarelling watch to prison, and the Sun sees the constable and the booke-keeper share fees the next morning.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thats not well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Yes, but they sweare tis well: the Moone sees bastards come bawling into the world, & the Sun sees'em shifted and shuffled in dossers, away to nurse, & thats the cause we haue so many dosser-heads: the Moone sees old curmudgeons come reeling from Tauerns with sipping of halfe pintes of Sack, and the Sun sees the same churles the next day, soberly cutting any mans throate for a pennie.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Enough of this: come hither: looke what here lyes.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: What here lyes: mary, father Subprior, the diuell and some Vsurers mony haue bin here at their lecherie, and see what goodly children they haue begot: if you will ile keepe the bastards at nurse.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I am content that halfe this gold he thine,
(If it bee ask'd for neuer, for tis not mine,)
So thou wilt promise tother halfe to giue
To such as I appoint.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: By this gold I will lay it out brauely, as you appoint me.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Looke not to prosper; if thou dealst amisse;
Good workes are keyes opening the gates of blisse,
That golden key, thou in that heape maist find;
If with it thou relieue the lame, sick, blind▪ & hungry

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: I will doe it I protest.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: One halfe bestow'd so, take thy selfe the rest.
So fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Farewell good father, a foole: Ile giue the blinde a dog to lead 'em, the lame shall to the whipping-post, the sick shall dye in a cage, and the hungry leap at a crust: I seede roagues, the pox shall: the world is changde: a begger yesterday, and full of gold to day: an asse to day, and a prow'd scab to morrow.

sp.speaker: Glit:
sp.p: Stay: stand.— Golden head ascends.

sp.speaker: Scu:
sp.p: Stand: cannot a Gentleman grow rich, but he must keepe knaues about him?

sp.speaker: Glit:
sp.p: That gold is none of thine.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: But all the craft in that great head of yours cannot get it out of my fangers. Zounds who the diuel art thou?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: A spirit sent vp from hell to make thee rich.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Thanke hell for it: hell makes worse foole rich in a yeere.

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: That gold I laide there for thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: When doe you lay againe, that I may haue more of these egges?

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.p: Spend those I charge thee first.

sp.speaker: Seu
sp.p: Yes, Head.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.p: And brauely I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: What neede you be at such charges, Ile doe't: but shall the poore be a pennie the better for me, as the old fellow charge me, yea, or no?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: No. ● Within?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Whos's that?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: Tis thine owne Genius cryes vnto thee no.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: My Genius, I am a cooke, my Genius then belike is a scullion; but when this is spent, can my Genius tell mee whither I shall haue more.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: More.

sp.speaker: Flat
sp.p: More.
More.
More.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Because my Genius keepes company with a great man, Ile take all their wordes; and his bond.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: When thou hast spent all that: I charge thee come
To the blacke tree, that stands in Naples groue,
Clymbe boldly to the top, and keepe fast hold,
For there ile rayne on thee a showre of gold,
If what thou seest there, thou to any tell,
Diuels shall teare thee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Seu
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: Ha, ha! downe downe bright spirit, thou wut bee mist anon, hell mynt stands ydle.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: Loose not that foole.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Be gon.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: Haue care to meete at next infernall court:
The day drawes nye.— Goes downe.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I thanke thee for this spirit.

div.stage: Enter K. Rufman, Narcisso, Spendola, Brisco, Iouinelli.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: You that complaine gainst Barteruile, (receiuer of all our tribute-monies) speak your wrongs; nay you haue deaff'd our cares too much already, hee does confesse your crownes (payde and receiude) but to giue backe your writings ther's no clause, If them youle win, fight it out by our lawes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I humbly thanke your highnes. A gratious doome.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: One day to try this plea, to hel thowlt come. Ex. 2.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Toth next, we ha businesse of our owne, toth' next:
O Barteruile! for these 200. crownes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I payde'em to that man.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Now afore the King
And his Lords here, thou liest: th'ast payde me none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Your chollers sirra too hye.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Tho my collar stand
So hye, it scarce beares vp this falling band.
Thou say'st thowlt sweare th'ast payd it: vds nailes sweare so,
And the fowle feende goe with't: 200. crownes?
I ha lost as much at loggets: sweare but to reuel,
And spend't in hel, gallop thee and that toth' diuel.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Man wherefore doest not sweare?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Reach me a booke.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let me before I sweare, on my notes look,
Ile tell you the very day; pray hold my staffe,
Till I draw out my false eyes.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Draw thy heart out an't wut: thou maist wel say thy false eyes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The day: August, 14.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Thats now, be damed, and so away.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: On this day (August, 14.) I sweare I payde
Into these hands, 200. crownes in gold.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Zounds not in siluer: by this booke I had none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: One of you two is periuriously forsworne.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: He, he, as I am true Curstian man.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: He sweares,
To your owne hands he payde them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Else let that eye,
Which sees me play false, scourge my periury
With fearefull stripes.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: O iustice I falne downe dead▪
Wud I had lost all▪ tho I had bin cozened,
Rather than thou thy soule.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: He bleedes at mouth.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: See his staffe (beating the earth, for heauen loues truth
Is burst in shiuers, and that gold he swore
Was pay'd to me, lyes scattred on the flore.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: He comes againe, the diuell will not receiue him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Take him away, weele punish him for this cryme.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Beg his office: you a Courtier?
I haue a suite to your highnes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What ist count Spendola?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Maister, looke vp man,
In this black trance had thy soule flyen away,
I had wrought hard and made a holliday.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Loose not a minute (pue-fellow) leaue him not yet,
I haue whales here too, lye playing in the net.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Ile take this gold at venture, (sweete yong King,)
For all this hel-hound owes me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Doe, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I am pay'd: the diuels turn'd puritane I feare,
He hates( me thinkes) to heare his own child sweare.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The office of this periurde Barteruile,
I frankly giue away, diuiding it
To the Count Spendola, and our worthy friend
Braue 〈◊〉 here; farme it to whom you please.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We thanke your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Spun
sp.l: Who bids most, he buyes it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If to his life▪ the diuel giues longer lease,
To build more worke for hel; goe see, & from him
〈…〉 of what he owes vs.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: That strict account Ile take.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Show him no fauour.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If now thou art a iust King, keepe thy word,
With thy poore subiects.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How now vncle? why

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This is thy day to heare the poore mans crye:
And yonders crying enough, at thy Court gates;
Fiue hundred 〈◊〉 heads, and scarce 10, good hats,
Yet haberdashers too, of all trades some,
Crying out they are vndon.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Vndon, by whom?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Mary, looke: by such as you are, who goe gay,
Weare't out, booke downe more, set to their hands but neuer pay;
Neuer in deare yeares was there such complayning
Of poore staru'd seruants, or (when plagues are raigning)
Mourne orphans so and widdowes, as those doe
That owe these sorrowfull papers.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray how can I
To their complainings adde a remedy?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Ile tell thee how: are any here in debt
To Merchants, Mercers, Taylors? let'em iet
In their owne sattins, pay for what they ha tane,
And these will goe lesse braue, tother lesse complaine.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The mightie wrongs the weake, the rich the poore,
This man should haue his owne, could he greaze more
His too-fat lawyer; that wretch for's coate does sue,
But his coat's gon, and his skin flead off too,
Ist his purse bee ore-match'd: these grosse impure
And ranck diseases, long vnto thy cure,
Thy word's in pawn fort, these are the poores cryes,
How wilt thou stop their throates?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: With halters.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Hang 'em! any halters here list so set down?
This law-booke speakes not so, yet tis thine own.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Still brauing me with this? burne it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yes doe.
If you burne all the weeke, burne saterday too:
Doe one good dayes-deed first, read poore mens plaints.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hels plagues confound 'em: in their heads and thine
Vex me no more.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I warrant thee ile saue mine.
Holy Saint pardon me, (las good father, my braine
So wilde is I forgot thee, but ile to him againe,
sp.p: Tis but an old mans head off. King take it, ile speake whilest this stands on my shoulders.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But that you are.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: An honest man, thou●'st haue this, ô I beseeke thy attention to this Reuerend sub●Prior,
sp.l: Who plaines against disorders of this House;
Where once Deuotion dwelt and Charitie,
Ther's Drunkennesse now, Gluttonie, and Lecherie,
Tell thou the Tale.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Bad Storie soone is tolde;
Because tis foule, that Leafe does all infolde,
Their sinnes grow hye, and fearefull, and strike at Heauen,
Punish them THOV, whose power from thence is giuen.

sp.speaker: K,
sp.l: Your Friers so lustie!

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: All the Barbers in Naples tell newes of that Priorie.

sp.speaker: Bris:
sp.p: I would your Grace would let me purge this house of her infection; bestowe the Liuings of it on mee, Ile sweeten it in one Moneth.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Heele lay it in▪ Lauender.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: The Couent, the Demeasnes, Immunities, Rents, Customes, Chartres, what to this house of Baall soeuer is belonging— Brisco tis thine.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.p: Wut rob the Church too, (Now th'ast nothing left▪ scarce for thy selfe?)

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: O heauen for-fend such theft!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bestowe it at thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Woe to those dayes,
When to raise Vpstarts, the poore CHVRCH decayes.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Call backe thy gift (ô King) and ere these eyes
Behold vnhallowed hands to Tyrannize
Where many a good man hys his Orisons said,
And many a Requiem bene sung out for the Dead,
(Till I am thrust out by Death) ô let mee haue
My dwelling there, there let me dig my Graue,
With mine owne Nayles, (shut vp from worldly Light,
Betweene two walls,) and dye an Anchoryte.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: I referre you to your Patron there.

sp.speaker: Rris:
sp.l: Thats I:
Shew mee first where your Abbey-gold sleeps, then goe dye.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: I feare RELIGIONS Fall: Alacke I see
This world's a Cittie built by the most Hie,
But kept by man, (GODS) greatest enemie.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Let ill-Newes flye together, thou art full of teares,
But I more full of woes, of cares, of feares.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: S'death shall wee haue yet faire weather?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Heeres one storme more.

sp.speaker: Ast:
sp.l: Calabrias Duke demaunds of you a Daughter.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let me but lye with's wife, Ile giue him a Sonne.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Hee sends for Erminghild.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Deliuer her.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Shees not to be found.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ya're an olde Foole,
To aske for that which is not.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Thus hee sayes,
Denie her and looke for warres.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: So goe your wayes.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I'me quickly gone.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: With Sacke ile sweare you are,
This was short and sweete,— Seemes then we shal ha warres,
Bohor, the Drumme must▪ scolde, the Canon thunder:
Fighting about a wench.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Tush, thats no wonder,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Who bayld him out of 〈…〉
Out of mine eye.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: I neuer begd before,
Pardon his crime (I intreate) and backe restore
Both your hye fauour to him, and his place.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let me want life, rather then want your Grace.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Doe you thinke Ile loose the Kings gift?

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Ile send you Golde.

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: That stops my mouth, pray let him still Sir hold,
This Office of Receiuer, I resigne
That part which I haue in it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: And I all mine.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Sirra, thanke these Lords.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I shall their loues deserue.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Barteruile, wee haue warres, Ile haue thee lend mee some▪ 30000. Chicquines at least.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Take all my Golde.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Wel, get you home with your bags sir, weele make bold.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: Your Maiestie shall haue what bags you will,
Bags onely, but Ile keepe my money still.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Now Shalcan, some newe Spirit.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A thousand wenches
Stark-nak'd, to play at Leap-frog.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Oh rare sight!

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Your vncle.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Sdeath, still haunted with this gray sprite.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: You need no Taylors now, but Armorers,
Theres a deere reckoning for you all to pay,
About a Ladie; the Calabrian Duke
Is on a March: the Lightning flashes now,
Youle heare the cracke anone. Before the starre
To call whome vp, the wakefull Cocke doth sing
Bee twice more seene abroad; At your Citie gates
The Diuells purseuant will beate (the Canon)
Will these briske leaders (stucke with Estridge-feathers▪)
Goe braue your enemie now, and beate his backe?
Saue thee, thy Kingdome, and themselues from wracke?

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Dotard, I scorne to take prescription
From any breath to which ours is supreame,
Stood Diuels with fire-works on your battlements,
A thousand Armed Ioues at your proude walls
Hurling forked Thunder, and the gates rambd vp
With piles of Citizens heads, our spring-tyde pleasures
No aduerse windes, no Torrent shall resist▪
Midst flames weele dance, and dye a Nerenist.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Fight you, yare good for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: They mocke vs.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: All starke mad: let vs be wise,
And flye from buildings falling to'th surer side,
If wee can his safety, if not, (our owne prouide.)

div.stage: Enter Barteruile like a Turke;— Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou hadst like t'ha sent mee swearing into Hell,
Ile weaue my Nettes my selfe, how doest thou like mee?
Is not this habite Turke-Merchant-like?

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: A meere Turke sir, none can take you for lesse.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: King borrow 30000. Chequines of mee! ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: But pray sir, what ist turnes you into a Turke?

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: That, for which manie their Religion,
Most men their Faith, all chaunge their honestie,
Profite, (that guilded god) Commoditie.
Hee that would grow damnd-Rich, yet liue secure,
Must keepe a case of Faces, sometimes demure.
Sometimes a grum-surly sir, now play the Iewe,
Then the Precisian; Not a man weele viewe.
But varies so. My selfe, (of bashfull nature)
Am thus supplyed by Arte.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mine owne deere creature.
But sit, your Aymes, and endes in this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Mary these—
A hundred thousand-Florens fill my Coffers,
Some of it is mine owne, and some the Kings,
Some taken vp at vse of sundry Merchants,
To pay at six six monthes, on mine owne band,)
Sue that, Ile keepe the monies in my hand.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Youle breake sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Not mine owne necke, but their backes;
To get their monies, Bartaruile must die,
Make will, name an executer, which am I.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Rare!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Giuen out his kinsman, lately imployed him in Turky.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What will hence befall?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Like an executer will I cozen all.
Make creditors Orphans, and widowes spend those teares
They sau'de from their late husbands burialls;
They get not ij. d. it'h pound.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Theile tell the King.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The King? ha ha: the King is going this way;
He meanes to borrow,
(If the warres holds) my gold: yes: when to morrow.
All debts of mine, on him shall be conferd,
iha breifes and tickets which from time to time
Shew what large summes his minions ha fetcht from me,
His tribute mony has payd it, that's no matter,
The world bites these dead, whom aliue they flatter.
And so must I; then giue it out I left
A compleate state, but the Kings death bereft
Me of those summes he owde.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Say the King preuailes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: With that wind must I likewise shift my saile:
And where the fox gets nothing, will turne Ape,
Make legges, crouch, kisse my paw, present some stale
Deuice of vertues triumph to expresse
How much I ioy him safe, with nothing lesse.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: But how can you excuse your turning Turke?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Easiest of all: Ile sweare, this saude my life,
Pursued by kennells of barking creditors:
For my much loue to him, and thus being forcde
To walke obscure, my credit fell to wracke,
Want of returne made all my factors breake,
In parts remote; to recompence which losse,
And that with safetie I may giue direction
To my disturbd state, craue I the Kings protection.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Protection! whats that?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A merchant, and yet know'st not
What a protection is? Ile tell thee.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Pray sir, for I neuer broke with any man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: It is a buckler of a large fayre compasse
Quilted within with Fox-skinnes: In the midst
A pike sticks out, (sometimes of two yeeres long,
And sometimes longer.) And this pike keepes off
Serieants and Bailiffs, Actions, and Arrests:
Tis a strong charme gainst all the noisome smels
Of Counters, Taylors, garnishes, and such hels;
By this, a debtor craizde, so lustie growes,
He may walke by, and play with his creditors nose.
Vnder this buckler, here ile lye and fence.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You haue out-reacht me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ile out-reache the diuell:
But I tempt danger: goe thou and fetch some Frier
As if (at point of death,) I did desire,
(No, Barteruile did desire (to make confession:
If any creditors beate, or raile at dore,
Vpstarts this Turke and answeres them.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why fetch I a Frier?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I haue a reaching plot in that (boy) hasten,
That we may smile in our securer port:
Seeing others sea tost: why tis but a sport
For him thats safe, to see the proud waues swallow
Whole fleetes of wretched soules: it needes must follow,
Nature sent man into the world, (alone,)
Without all company, but to care for one, and that ile doe.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: True Citie doctrine sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Away, thy hast, our richest loue shall earne,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I came to teach, but now( me thinkes) must learne.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: What saies the prodigall child in the painted cloth? when all his mony was spent and gon, they turnd him out vnnecessary; then did hee weepe and wist not what to don, for he was in's hose and doublet verily, the best is, there are but two batches of people moulded in this world, thats to say Gentlemen and Beggers; or Beggers and Gentlemen, or Gentlemanlike Beggers, or Beggerlike Gentle-men; I ranck with one of these I am sure, tag and rag one with another: Am I one of those whom Fortune fauours? No no, if Fortune fauourd me, I should be full, but Fortune fauours no body but Garlicke, nor Garlike neither now, yet she has strong reason to loue it; for tho Garlicke made her smell abhominably in the nostrills of the gallants, yet she had smelt and stuncke worse but for garlike: One filthy sent takes away another. She once smilde vpon me like a lambe, when shee gaue me gold, but now she roares vpon me like a Lion. Stay: what said head? Spend this brauely, and thou shalt haue more: can any prodigall new-come vpstart spend it more brauely? and now to get more, I must goe into the groue of Naples thats here, and get into a blacke tree, heares a blacke tree too, but art thou he?

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: He.— within.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Ha ha, where art thou my sweete great head?

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: Head.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: O'at the head, thats to say at the top: how shall I get vp? for tis hard when a man is downe in this world to get vp, I shall neuer climbe hie.

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: Hye.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: I will hie me then, but I am as heauy as a sow of lead.

sp.speaker: Giltt.
sp.l: Leade.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Yes, I will lead (big Head) whatsoeuer followes, Many a gallant for gold, has climbde higher on a gallowes 'The storme euen as Head nodded) is comming: Cooke, licke thy fingers, now or neuer.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: Now or neuer.

div.stage: Rayne, Thunder and lightning: Enter Lucifer and Diuels.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: This is the tree.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: On which would you all were hang'd, so I were off it, and safe at home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And this (I am sure tis this) the horrid groue
Where witches broodes ingender, (our place of meeting.)

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Doe witches ingender here: zounds I shall bee the diuels bawde whilest he goes to his lecherie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And this the hideous black infernall howre:
Hanno appearance yet? if their least minute
Our vassailes breake, sinck shall these trees to hell.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This groue ile turne into a brimstone lake
Which shall be euer-burning.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: The best is, if I be a match in the diuels tinderbox, I can stinck no worse than I doe alreadie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not yet come▪ Oooh!

div.stage: Enter Shacklesoule, Rufman, embrace, and Lurchall, at seuerall dores with other diuels.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh, oooh.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Sure the feare no Christian
Diuels, they so loue one another.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Stand forth.

div.stage: Sits vnder the tree all about him.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Frier Rush amongst 'em

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And here vnlade you of that pretious freight
For which you went, (mens soules;) what voyage is made?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No sauing voyage, but a damning.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: I thought the diuell was turnde Merchant, theres so many Pirates at Sea.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Ith Court of Naples haue I prospred well,
And braue soules shall I shortly ship to hell▪
In sensuall streames, Courtier and King I ha crownde,
From whence warre is flowing, whose tyde shall all confound.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Are there gentlemen diuels too? this is one of those, who studies the black Art, thats to say, drinkes Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are all then good ith Citie?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: No nor scarce ith suburbes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Great Prince of diuels,
Thy hests I haue obayde,
I am bartring for one soule, able to lade
An Argocy; if Citie, oathes, if periuries,
Cheatings, or gnawing mens soules by vsuries,
If all the villanies (that a Citty can,)
Are able to get thee a sonne, I ha found that man.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Serue him vp,— stands vp.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Alas, now now.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Damnation giues his soule but one turne more,
Cause he shall be enough.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Its no meruaile if markets be deere, when the Citie is bound to find the diuell roast-meate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Has Rush lyen ydle?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Ydle? no Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: All the world is turnd diuell. Rush is one too,

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Ydle? I haue your nimblest diuell bin,
In twentie shapes begetting sin.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: One was to get me thrust out of the priory.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I am fishing for a whole schoale of Friers.
Al are gluttoning or muttoning, stabbing or swelling
Ther's onely one Lambe scapes my killing,
But I will haue him: then theres a cooke.—

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Whose arse makes buttons.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Of whom I some reuenge haue tooke.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: The diuell choake you fort.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: He mickle scath has done me,
And the knaue thinkes to out-run me.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Not too fast.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Kick his guily soule hither.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Ile driue him to despaire,
And make him hang himselfe.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: For hanging I stand faire.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: Goe, ply your workes, our Sessions are at hand.

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.l: We fly to execute thy dread command.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Would I could flye into a bench-hole!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But what haue you don? nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: We haue all like bees
Wrought in that Hyue of soule (the busie world:)
Some ha lyen in cheesmongers 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Wud I were there but 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: For one halfe ounce, we had 〈…〉 soule

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: If he melted tallow, hee smelt sweetly as I doe.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: Walke round hels shambles, thou shalt see there sticks
Some 4. butchers soules, puft queintly vp with pricks.

sp.speaker: Scu. 4.
sp.l: Sweete-breads I hold my life, that diuels an asse.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: Taylors ore-reachers, for to this tis growne,
They scorne thy hell, hauing better of their owne.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: They feare not sattin nor all his workes.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: I haue with this fist beate vpon rich-mens hearts,
To make 'em harder: and these two thumbes thrust,
(In open Churches) into braue dames eares.
Damning vp attention; whilst the loose eye peeres
For fashions of gowne-wings, laces, purles, ruffes,
Fals, cals, tires, wires, caps, hats, and mufs, and pufs.
For so the face be smug, and carkas gay,
Thats all their pride.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Twill be a festiuall day
When those sweete Duckes comes to vs: loose 'em not: goe:
More soules you pay to hell, the lesse you owe.
This Ewe-tree blast with your hot-scorching breath,
A marke, (toth' witch who next sits here) of death.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ooooh.— Fireworkes: Scumbroath falls.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Call you this, rayning downe of gold? I am wet toth' skinne in the showre, but tis with sweating for feare: had I▪
now had the conscience that some Vintners and Inholders haue? here might I haue gotten the diuell and all. But two sinnes haue vndone me, prodigalitie, and couetousnesse: and three Pees haue pepperd me, the Punck, the Pot, and Pipe of smoake, out of my pocket my gold did soake. I cannot sweare now, zounds I am gallant: but I can sweare as many of the ragged Regiment doe, zounds I haue bin a gallant. But I am now downe, deiected, and debash'd, and can better drawe out a thirdendale gallant, thats to say, a gallant that wants of his true measure, than any tapster can draw him out of his scores: thus he sets vp and thus hee's pulls downe; thus is he raised and thus declinde:
sp.l: Nominatiuo, Hic Gallantus, a Gallant.
Genetiuo, Hugious, braue.
Datiuo Huic, If he gets once a lick,
Accusatiuo Hunc, Of a taffaty Punck.
Accusatiuo Hunc, 〈…〉
Hunc, Hunc, & Hoc, With 〈◊〉 vp her smock▪
〈…〉 Hees gon if he cryes so.
〈…〉 Away with him, he has the pock▪
〈…〉 If the pox 〈…〉,
Genetiuo, Horum, Yet hees a begger in coram.
Datiuo, His: His gilt rapier he does misse.
Accusatiuo Hos, Without his cloake he goes.
Accusatiuo Has, To the Counter he must passe.
Hos, has▪ & Hae●, With two Catchpols at his back.
〈…〉! A hole he desirde, and to th' hole he must goe.
Ablatiuo, ab His, Thus many a Gallant declined is.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Daughter to the Calabriam Duke.
The haples troth-plight wife to your sad King.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Alack! what notes are these I heare you sing?
Pardon me madam:
O Lady! want of you has bred much woe;
Calamitie does euery where ore-flow,
All long of your strange absence.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I confesse,
Loaden with your Kings contempt▪ and loath to beare
Shame to my country▪ who from thence came freighted
With many glorious honours, I preferd
An obscure life before a publick shame;
O then (good father) be it not my blame
If my supposde death, on the King haue throwne,
Dangers, which from himselfe are meerely growne.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What (princely Mayden) would you wish me doe?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I doe coniure you sir, by all the bonds
Tye you to pious Acts, you would make way
To my incensed father; giue him these lines,
This Ring, pledge of that blessing he deliuerd me
At our last parting: adde vnto these, if euer
His daughters memory to him were deare,
To wound the Prince let his rash hand forbeare:
Since through each wound he giues him, I am slaine,
If the sad king you meete, venture to tell him
That more for him, than he for me, I bide,
And am his subiect stil, tho not his bride.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: This shall I doe, how shall we meete againe?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Feares follow me so, I know not where nor when.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Hearke how the sound of horror beates the Ayre,
Your fathers vp in Armes and does prepare
Sharpe vengeance, for this citie, woe is me: trust you
To me, who nere made much of woman yet,
Rest here sweete maide, till an old Frier beget
What ioyes he can to comfort thee? Is Clement growne
A womans man now? No, I am not mine owne,
Where your command may sway me:
Much more in this,
Where heauen) through vertues triall) makes you his.

div.stage: A table is set out with a candle burning, a deaths head, a cloke and a crosse; Subprior sits reading: Enter Shackle-soule, leading in an Italian Zany, fiue or 6. Gurtizans, euery one holding a Iewell.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: That's he, & theres your golden hire to charme him;
Your fees ile treble, let but lusts flame be felt;
The Alpine-snow at the sun's beames does melt,
So let your beauties thaw his frozen Age,
Musick first t'act an old Lecher, then a diuell on hells black Stage:
Strike, strike your siluer strings: braue set of whores?
At your striking vp, diuells dance, and all hell roares.

div.stage: Zany and Curtizans fall into a short dance,

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What sound offends mine eare? Soule of temptation?
Enchanters I defie yee, get you gon;
Ime blind to your enticements, from this I learne,
At how deere rate the careles world does earne.
That thing calld pleasure: how many soules doe fall?
(Sold for a little guilt top daube this wall?)
Hence with your witchcrafts, the sight of this driues hence,
All thoughts besieging our voluptuous sence.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Another baite, at this he will not bite.

div.stage: The Zany singes: Subprior holds his head downe as fast a sleepe.

sp.speaker: Zany.
sp.l: Will you haue a daintie girle? here tis:
Currall lippes, teeth of pearle: here tis:
Cherry checkes, softest flesh; that's shee,
Breath like May, sweete and fresh; shee shee.
Be she white, blacke, or browne,
Pleasure your bed shall crowne,
Chose her then, vse her then,
Women are made for men.
Prettie, prettie wast:
Sweete to be embracde:
Prettie leg, ô prettie foote,
To beauties tree the roote▪
This is she shall doo'te,
Or she shall doo't, or she shall doo't, she shall doo't, she shall doo't
Kisse, kisse, play, play, come and dally,
Tumble, tumble, tumble, in beauties valley.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: His soule is chaind in pleasures, bind it fast,
If he breake your charmes▪ the strongest spell comes last.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Hence diuells incarnate, tis not the sorcerie
Of your deceitfull tunes, shuts vp mine eye,
Mine eares are likewise stop'd, hence, hence I say.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha, a man of yee, a clod of clay.

div.stage: Enter Shackle soule, or some spirit in a frightfull shape.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Are all thy incantations spent now? art come againe?
Base workmanship of heauen, what other traine,
Were all hells frightfull horrors stucke in thy looke,
Thou canst not shake me.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I can.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thou liest, thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I bring thee tydings of thy death this night.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: How doest thou know that houre of my last fight?
False herald, Minister of despaire and lyes.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I know to how many minutes thy daies must rise.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Who giues thee the number.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: All things to vs are knowne,
What euer haue bin, are, or shalbe don.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Ile pose thee presently, whats this thou fiend▪
Which now I haue turnd too, doe but tell me that
And ile belieue thee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I scorne to be thy slaue.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Downe, downe, and sincke into thy damned caue:
Looke here, doest fly thou hell-hound? I dare thee stand,
Or'e thee by these holy spells haue I strong command,
Thy battries are too weake: by goodmens prayers,
The continence of saints, (by which as stayres,
They ascend to heauen) by Virgins chastitie;
By Martirs cround deaths, which recorded lye
In siluer leaues, aboue: I charge thee downe,
Howle where tha'rt bound in slauerie, till the last dome,

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Stormes, thunder, lightning, rip vp the earths wombe.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Eternall power, thankes on my humbled knee,
Thou still to constant brests giu'st victory.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: No way to conquer thee? Ile giue thee ore:
Ne're fishd I so, (yet lost a soule) before.

div.stage: Allarums▪ Enter King, Rufman, Spendola, Brisco, with drawne weapons. Iouinelli here.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Blacke horrors, mischiefe ruine and confusion affright vs, follow vs.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Dare them to the face,
And you fright them.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: No safetie but to fly.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Whither Spendola, whither? better stay, and die.

div.stage: Enter Narcisco: King, Allarums afar of.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: What hope? what newes?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Is my vncle fled?

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: Hees is gon:— And fights against you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Follow him damnation,
That leaues his Prince so in distresse, in miserie;
O bane of Kings! (thou inchanting flatterie,)
Thy venome now I feele, eating my heart,
More mortall than an Indians poisned dart.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Year'e too deiected, gather head and fight it out.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The head's here, where are hands to lay about?

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The man that title mockes
Is here, (thou sad-visage man) are any hirde to kill me,
Or betray me? let 'em come:
Griefes growing extreame, death is a gentle doome.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Prepare then for the worst.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am armd fort: shew it.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Thy kingdome is a weake ship, bruizd, split, sinking,
Nor hast thou any pilot to waft vs o're
Out of this foule Sea, to some calmer shore.
Thy peoples hearts are turnd to rocks of flint,
The Scholler, Souldier, and the Mariner,
Whom (as themselues say) once thou trodst vpon,
Now serue as wheeles of thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Flying swiftly backward, the kingly Lions quaild,
What shall the weaker heardes doe, if he fall?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Lets fly.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Zounds whither?

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: So we may be safe—

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: But where?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: At Barteruile: the churle's to me beholden,
His house so stands, we may enter without feare.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Beet so, to Barteruile.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: What will your Highnes doe?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Die Spendola, a miserable King,
None here can hinder vs of that.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: How? die?— ha you any stomach to death sirs?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Not I.
Troth's, tho you grow desperate, weele grow wise.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Farewell sir, weele saue one.—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh my cruelst enemies!
Stabs Brutus at me too?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Now mine owne or neuer.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why art not thou gon?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: I, Ile sticke to you euer:
I am no Courtier sir of fortunes making

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou art no wiseman to preferre thy loue.
To me, before thy life, pray thee leaue me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I shall not hate the world so really
As else I would, O had the ancient race
Of men (who had long leases of their liues)
Bin wretched as we are, no recompence
Could the Gods haue giuen them for their being here,
But now more pittifull wise nature growes,
Who cuts of mans yeeres to cut off his woes.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: True sir, & teaches him a thousand waies
To leade him out this horrid giddy maze.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I apprehend thee, a small daggers point,
Opens the vaines to cure our plurizy.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Than to be made your foes-slaue, better dye.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A hundred thousand deaths, than like a captiue
Be chaind to grace prowd Caesars Chariot wheele.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Much lesse a pettie Dukes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Fetch me deare friend,
An armed Pistoll, and mouth it at my brest:
Ile make a way my selfe, and all my sorrowes
Are made away.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: The best and nobler spirits
Haue done the like.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Your brauest men at Armes
Haue done the like.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Philosophers haue don it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Great peeres haue don it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Kings haue done the like.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And I will doe it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Nay it shall nere be said,
I liu'd a minute after you: here, here.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I embrace thee noblest friend.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Lets saile together.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Content braue Bohor: oh! but whither? whither?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: From hell, (this world,) from, fiends, (in shapes of men.)

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No: into hel, from men to be dambd black with fiends.
Me thinkes I see hell yawne to swallow vs.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Fuh, this is but the swimming of your braine,
By looking downe-wards with a timerous eye.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: My soule was sunck too low, to looke more hye,
Forgiuenes heauen.— Allarums.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: The whippes of furies lash mee: the foe comes on.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And we will meete him, dare confusion,
And the worlds mixed poisons, there is a hand
That fights for Kings, and vnder that weele stand.

div.stage: Allarum still a farre off: Enter a Frier running.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Whither runnes this Frier?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: To saue my wretched life,
From th'insolent soldier, threatning the Cities spoile.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Of what house art thou?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Of father Clements Order, The Capachines Subprior: a quick messenger fetched me to be rich Barteruiles confessor, who lyes a dying.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A dying!

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: He does, but I
Haue come thus far, with so much ieopardy.
That could I safely get the keys shore,
Nor the priory would I see more.
For charities sake, direct me, and defend me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: To helpe destressed men, religion bindes me,
Shouldst thou in this hot broiles, be met abroad,
It will be iudgde you leaue your Priory,
Carying gold and siluer with you.

sp.speaker: Eri.
sp.l: Las I haue none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But Frier if you be thus taken, your life is gon,
Here, here, cast off thy habit, better that lye
Ith Streetes than thou poore wretch; weare mine, & away
Strike downe that lane.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Thankes maister, for your liues ile pray.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This Bohor shall disguise me, whither wilt thou fly.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Ile shift I warrant: hast thou toth' Priory.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If we nere meete againe, (best friend) farewell.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Not meete, yes, I hope, you must not thus cheate hel.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I will not trust this fellow: toth' Priory, no:
Barteruiles Confessor: if to betray
Thou findst the churle apt, leaue him, if not, there stay,
The downefall of that Prince, is quick and steepe.
Who has no heart to leaue, nor power to keepe,

div.stage: Enter Barteruile and Lurchall, with the Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Make the doore sure the house is round beset.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Beset!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Put vp: feare nothing: Armies should they enter, Cannot here find you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How shall we escape?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Send for your truncks and iewels, ile ship you this night meane time, this vnknowne way, leads to a cellar, where a world cannot fetch you forth: In, In, if danger pursue you, in a dry-fat Ile packe you hence.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Zounds into the dungeon?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So to Sardini:
Your cloakes and your gilt rapiers downe, downe, downe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How soone meetes Babels-pride, confusion?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What nest of birds are these new-kild with feare?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fowle cannot last long sweete, therefore kept there Serieants.
In my cold cellar; stay, house beset? what sees?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Such as strike dead the heart, yet giue no blowes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This— footra for 'em: proclamations Lurchall,
6000. Crownes are his, can these betray,
Soone earnd, weele share fetch, the Calabriam hither,
They are here say: dam 'em.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You shall be dambd together.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Wher's that deuote sicke man desires to take
Leaue off this world? Deus hic to all now here.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now Domine Frier; what I to you confesse
You are bound by oath to keepe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I auer no lesse.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Keepe then this close, I am no Turke, not I,
But Barteruile disguisde in pollicy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Are you the Sickman.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sick of a disease,
Bad as a plague to Citizens, I must breake,
Play a banckrowts part) I haue monie of the kings,
Of merchants, Ile keepe all, these are Citie-springs;
Here lyes Serieants Leaguer: about my doores:
My house to me is an hospitall, they the sores
Which run vpon me vily, (peepe I but out.)
To raize this Dunkirke seige, thus cast I about.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Lets heare, pray how?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thus, thus sweete Domine Frier,
Ile be like you, a Capuchine: So, by your Prior,
Sub-prior, and couent, I may be fetcht hence,
Spite of all Showlder-clappers violence.
Tho the King should lay hands on me, I wud not tary.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You neede not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are my guard, my Sanctuary.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But what your leuel in this, when this is don?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Alas▪ what leuell but pure deuotion?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The Diuell you haue.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: When I dye there, take All:
Will you goe to your prior and tell this?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yes I shall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ile send him an earnest peny (a 100. Crownes)
As the first stone my charitie builds vpon.
What drom's this? come, dispatch Frier, and be gon.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Out of this hell thou meanest: yes ile fly from thee
As from the Diuels hangman: thowl't else betray mee.
World▪ to what crest of villanie art thou growne?
When (of good men) whole kingdomes scarce breede One.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Here's the Duke of Calabria sir if you haue made mee tell a lye, theile send me of a voiage to the yland of Hogs and Diuels, (the Barmudas,) the Duke sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His grace is welcome, las! I had more neede
To haue Phisitions and Apothecaries,
Than fighters at my gates: Lurchall why come they?

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.l: Deliuer vp those monsters in thy house,
That haue deuourd a Kingdome and the King.
Tis death to thee, and him, if thou detainst 'em.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I detaine 'em, here, here, here.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Reward if thou deliuerst them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ime past rewarding in this world, I looke onely for good mens prayers, theres the key Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Vnbind him: stay why did thy house receiue them?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Full fore against my will: the bed I rise from
Count I my death-bed; for (each minute) I looke
When Angells (heauens good porters) will let me in,
Yet (like my betters) I'me heauy laden with sin.
And being thus sicke, and at last gaspe, I sent for my neerst cozen, my executor,
Who seeing braue fellowes beating at my gates,
Tooke 'em for honest men, let 'em in simply,
And vndertooke this night, to ha shipd 'em hence;
My faithfull Seruant telling me this, (In zeale,
To you and my country) I bid him, All reueale.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thast plaid a Subiects part in't.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Heele lead you to them.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My Lord, take force and seize 'em, nere stand vpon
More trialls; giue 'em speedie execution.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Come fellow.—

div.stage: Exeunt Ast: and Lurchall cum Militibus.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your grace has don with me?

sp.speaker: Caleb
sp.l: Goe, looke to thy health:
The crownes the proclamation promised,
Shall to thy man be payd.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thankes to your Grace:
Las what I did in this, was for no hire.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha ha, the rent of a cellar neuer was so deere.
On beate the drum.

div.stage: As they goe off; Enter Octauio with Rufman and a guard.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Are the rest tanc?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The graund-Pyrat's here.
Heres the Diuells bellowes, kindled all those fires,
Which now are burning: This is the Snake, whose sting
(being kept warme in the bosome of a King)
Struck him to'th heart: This hee, who by the force
Of his damb'd Arguments, was the first diuorce,
Of the Kings Loue, this is Bohor.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This that Serpent,
Y'haue all (like Traytors) wrought a Princes fall,
And all shall taste one death.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Sirra, wheres the King?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Warrant mee life, ile bring you to the place where you shall take him.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Wult thou betray him Slaue?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou shalt haue life.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: And you the King shall haue.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: And the Gallows shall haue thee, else hang me. Away

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.l: Alas, whereas the sub Prior?

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Here, what ailest thou?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Can you picke nothing out of my face?
Is there not a Deaths-head standing on my shoulders?

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Scu:
sp.l: The Lord Pryor is called away:

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Whither, by whome?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: By the Great-head, I thinke he couzened mee,
Hee is gone to the blacke-squibbe-tree, to
Iudas Oke! set by the Diuell, I tolde you then,
I saw Frier Rush spit fire amongst other Hel-cats,
and yee woud not belieue me▪ Now I tell you,
that the Pryor is choackt; will his choaking
goe downe your throate?

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: How choackt?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.p: Yes, choackt: that of which men die ore-night, and are well the next morning, wine has kild the Lorde Pryor: he woud in a brauerie taste the liquor of our Vines, because you threatned he should neuer licke his lippes after. And the Kernell of a grape stopt his winde-pipe, for want of a skowring-sticke.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Art thou sure hee is dead?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.l: How dead, because I wud be sure,
I cut his throate of purpose, to take out the Kernell.

sp.speaker: Sub:
sp.l: Most fearefull and prodigious, whither runst thou?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.p: To see more throates cut, and Execution of certaine Gallants is this morning. And I came running to see them, who like a whore spoyles euery good thing that comes into his hand. The hang-man, I leaue you to the Gallowes.

div.stage: Enter Barteruile like a Frier, brought in by the Subprior, the King, Shackle-soule, and Lurchall, with others.

sp.speaker: Rush:
sp.l: Welcome deare brother: now your heede must be
Not to looke backe at this worlds vanitie,
Riches and pleasures: you haue laide aside
That Garment, and must now be mortifide.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: I am mortifide, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: So is the Diuell.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Your Gold and siluer, you must see no more.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: O Fye! giue it euery farthing to the poore,
When I haue sent for't hither.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: That will be neuer.

sp.speaker: Rush:
sp.l: Your money shalbe spent in pious sort.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: I know that: Let my soule be the better for't,
That's all I craue for, after I am dead.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Many a Requiem for it shall be said.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: What Drum is this?

sp.speaker: Shack.
sp.l: Fryers stand vpon your Guard.
The Priorie is beset with Armed-men,
Of which some Troupes are entred.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am betrayd.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Lurchall I feele my wezand pipe cut.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I warrant you.

div.stage: Enter Calabria, Octauio, Astolfo, Rufman led by two holding pistalls, Souldiers, drums, and Cullors.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Guard the Abbey gates, let not a Frier goe forth:
You haue a King amongst you, which is he?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A King!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I know of none here.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Villaines you lie:

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This caitife does delude you, tortur him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hang him, and these vp or'e the Abbey walls,
Our wrath shall smite like thunder where it falls.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I shall like a dog, die without money, Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Tyran, that royall hart thou huntst, is here,
Stand from me all, you haue betrayd me all,
And ile trust none of you, if the Lion must fall,
Fall shall he like a Lion; thinkst thou (base Lord)
Because the glorious Sun behind blacke cloudes
Has a while hid his beames, hees darkned for euer?
Ecclipsd neuer more to shind, yes, and to throw
Fires from his sparkling eyes, thee to confound,
Touch not that noble friend of mine, (It seemes,
For my sake markd for danger,) let your arrowes
(Dipd in rancke poyson) be shot all at me,
Since all is lost, die nobly, and loose life too:
O vncle! must the first dart fly from you?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Into thy bosome fly I.

sp.speaker: Kin
sp.l: To betray me?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: To fight for thee till I can fight no more:
Hadst thou possest this Kingly spirit before,
We ne're had left thee: what makes Iudas here?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Heres he that to the Duke thy life betraide.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bohor!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I, Bohor.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I told him where you were.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I tell thee tha'rt a traitor & ile haue
Thy head off, or thou mine.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Head?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Thart a slaue?
Thou seest Duke what to trust too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I haue confest, and shal be hangd, the King?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Our faire game come to this? our swordes I see▪
Must from your hearts-blood let out al my wronges?
A murdred daughter for iust vengeance cryes,
Whom to appease, your liues weele sacrafize:
Beate the drom.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thunder mock thunder, beats ours.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O let these fires be quenchd out with my teares,
If waters cannot, (Duke) I bind thy rage
With this strong charme, and this read ore that spell,
And let thy hard brest grow more flexible.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Where's Iouinelli; and that bastard crue
Of my false friendes?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Beheaded.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: They haue their due.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The ring I gaue her, and her hand: old man,—
Where's the old Frier deliuerd these?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hees gon.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Make after him, tis some delusion.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Tis no delusion (father) am I the ground
Of this your quarrell, which must both confound
If you goe on: your battailes thus Ile part,
The first blow giuen, shall run cleane through my heart▪
Oh noble constant maid, forgiue my wrongs,
The warmth of heauen to a pyning spring
Cannot such comfort giue as thy glad presence
Does to my bosome.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Will you fight or no?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Twere madnes to wish stormes when faire windes blow:
Will you your faith yet keepe?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Inuiolate.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Then here end all my warres.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And all my hate.
Hast all these Friers vp to the Abbey walles,
And with shrill voyces, this our peace proclaime,
Stay holy father: Bohor, See you this don.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: Vengeance, I haue now lost more than I haue won.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I shall goe scot free Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Passing well?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They doe not smell me, yet my selfe I smell.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Why sends your Hignes, thus these Friers to play
Your heralds parts in publishing this peace?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: There's in't a riddle (vncle) which by none but by these Friers onely, can be don.— Enter Friers aboue. So: are you mounted? Sing now.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Sing.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Yes sing,
Like Swannes before your deathes: there you all shall dye;
Ciue fire to this most damned priory.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Alacke for pitty!

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Father, but for thee,
Thunder from heauen had (long ere this) to dust
Grinded these hellish buildings: that hand was iust,
Which struke your vitious Prior, so is our doome,
That Synagogue of diuells, let fire consume.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But meanes the King that I shall burne here too?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou? the grand villaine, giue him a villaines due.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am no Frier, see I'me poore Barteruile.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How? Barteruile?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He lyes the slaue's a Turke.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A Christian by this hand, Your officer.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The cittie canker, the courts cozener,
A diuell in shape of man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Halfe that I haue
I freely giue, so you my life will saue.
Ile lend your Hyghnes 30000. chequines.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Ten Kingdomes cannot buy thee; were there 10. hels
Thart dambd in all, S'death! fie that house of diuels.

sp.speaker: 3. Diu.
sp.l: Doe: lets not want light to set forth our Reuels.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: King, little doest thou know, whom (all this while)
Thy court, this Couent, and this Barteruile,
Haue entertaind: of hell, 3. Spirits we are.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Sent to catch soules for Pluto, our Prince and maister.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Defend vs heauens.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Thy selfe hast burst those bandes
In which I once held thee: these are in our handes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: If you be right Serieants, for mony youle let mee goe. 5000 Crownes ile giue but to goe home.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: 3. No.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ile put in 4. brokers to be my baile: I hope theile be (taken.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Yes as thou art, (to hell,) you dog leaue howling.
This pile of greene young diuels, needes no fire
Of mortals kindling to consume, these frames,
You shall with vs to hell ride, all in flames.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Catch.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: 3. Come.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Let euery spirit his owne prize beare

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: They are so heauy with sin, theile soone be there.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Away then and be dambd, wud you all were here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh— Sinck downe, aboue flames.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Immortall thankes for our deliuerance:
Race to the ground those wals: no stone shall stand,
To tell such place was euer in our land,
What welth can there be found, giue to the poore,
Another house weele build and thee restore,
To former virginitie: weepe not for these ruines,
Thou shalt from vs haue honours. Here we begin
Our reigne anew, which golden threds shall spin,
Iustice shall henceforth sit vpon our throne,
And vertue be your Kings companion.
Warre here resignes his black and horrid stage
To sportfull Hymen, God of Mariage.

div.stage: The play ending, as they goe off, from vnder the ground in seuerall places, rise vp spirits, to them enter, leaping in great ioy, Rufman, Shackle soule, and Lurchall, discouering behind a curten, Rauillac, Guy Faulx, Barteruile, a Prodigall, standing in their torments.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Spir. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Dam. Torments in-vtterable! oh! dambd for nothing?

sp.speaker: Rauill.
sp.l: Terrors incomprehensible.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Back: y'are blowne vp else.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Whooh: hot, hot, hot,- drinck,- I am heart-burnt.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: One drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Faul.
sp.l: Now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I am perbold, I am stewd, I am sod in a kettle of brimstone, pottage.— it scaldes,— it scaldes,— it scaldes,— it scaldes— whoo●

sp.speaker: Diu.
sp.l: Ha ha ha:

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: But one halfe crom, a little little drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Faul.
sp.p: Towers, towers, towers, towers, pinnacles & towers, battlements and pynnacles, steeples, abbeys, churches and old chimnyes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Zounds drinke, shall I choake in mine Inne? drinck.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Drinck, drinck, oh! one drop, one drop, to coole vs.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: So many tapsters in hell, and none fill drinck here:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ball no more, you shall be liquord.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Why art thou dambd toth' horrors of one hell,
Yet feelst ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Wherefore is thy soule
Made sensible of tortures which (each minute)
Kill thee ten thousand times, yet canst not dye?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Some sacke.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Why for a few sinnes that are long hence past,
Must I feele torments that shall euer last? Euer euer.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let the sacke be mulld.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Why is the diuell,
(If man be borre good) suffred to make him euill?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Man is an asse, if he sit broyling thus ith glasse house
sp.p: Without drinke: two links of my chaine for a three halfe peny bottle of mother consciences Ale: drinke.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: One drop of puddle water to coole vs.

div.stage: Enter Shackle soule with a burning torch, and a long knife, Lurchall with a handfull of Snakes, A third spirit with a ladle full of molten gold, All three make a stand, laughing.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Leaue howling and be dambd.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Heres drinke for thee royall villaine.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Shac
sp.l: Ist not good!
For bloud th'ast thirsted, and thy drinke is bloud.
Strikes it so cold to thy heart? heres that shall warme thee (Agen.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Damnation, furies, fire-brandes.—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: One drop of moisture, but one crum.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Art hungry, eate this adder: dry? Sucke this Snake.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Sucke and be dambd thy selfe: Ile starue first. Away

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is not this all waters? Ruby water, some Ruby water,
Or els a bottle of posterne water to saue charges, or els a
Thimble-full of lymon water, to coole my stomach the ru-●

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: By is swilld vp all, heres lymon, downe with't.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Foh, the great diuell or els some Aquauite woman has made water, It scalds me.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh.

sp.speaker: Diu.
sp.l: Ha ha ha▪—

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hell grinnes to heare this roaring: wheres this black child of faddomles perdition? rarest diuell
sp.l: That euer hould in Barathrum? here, (deere pupill)
Of a new damnations stamp, Saucer-eyde Lucifer,
has drunke to thee this deepe infernall boule off,
Wut pledge his vglines?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Reach it mee.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Choake with it.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Giue fire, blow all the world vp.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Bounce: tis don. Ha ha ha.—

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I shalbe grinded into dust; It falls: I am mad.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: I am mad, I am mad.—

sp.speaker: And
sp.l: 4. Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Others.
sp.l: Ho ho ho.—

div.stage: Enter Pluto, attended by Minos, Aeac us, and Rhadamanth, and 3. Faries.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Fetch whippes of poysoned steele, strung with glouing wires.
And lash these saucie hell-hounds: ducke their soules,
Nine times toth' bottome of our brimstone lakes,
From whence vp pull them by their sindged hayre,
Then hang'em in ropes of yce nine times frozen o're:
Are they scarce hot in hell, and must they roare?
What holliday's this? that heres such grinning, ha!
Is hell a dancing Schoole? yare in extreames,
Snoring, or els horne-mad? who are set on shore,
On this vast land of horror, that it resounds,
With laughter stead of shrikes, who are come to our bounds? ha!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Dread Lord of this lower tortary, to thy Iayle
Haue we thy busie Catch-polls (prisoners) brought
Soules, for whose comming all hell long hath sought.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Their names: Is Ward and Dantziker then come?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Yes: Dantziker is come.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Wheres the dutch Schellum? wheres hells factor 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Charon has bound him for a thousand yeeres,
To tug ats oare: he scourd the Seas so well,
Charon will make him ferriman of hell.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Where's Ward?

sp.speaker: Rush.
sp.l: The Merchants are not pilld nor pulld enough,
They are yet but shauen, when they are fleade, hee'le come.
And bring to hell fat booties of rich theeues,
A crew of swearers and drinkers the best that liues.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ward is not ripe for damming yet.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Who is it then?
Cutlar the Serieant: ha! he come.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Yes Pluto:
Cutlar has bin here long, sent in by a carman,
But his sterne lookes the feindes did so displease,
Bound hand and foote, he houles in little ease,
Hauing onely mace to comfort him: he does yell,
And raue, because he cannot rest in hell.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Tis not for him, that we this holliday hold.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: The baude of Shorditch, Is that hellcat come?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: No: but sha's bin a long time lanching forch,
In a Rosa-solis-barke.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Diuells! who is it then?
Mall Cutpurse is she come?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Our cosen come? No.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Tis not yet fit Mall Cutpurse here should houle,
Shee has bin too late a sore-tormented soule.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Where is our daughter? ha? Is shee ydle?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No.
Shee was beating hemp in bridewell to choke theeues,
Therefore to spare this shee ramp she beseeches,
Till like her selfe all women weare the breeches.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mall Cutpurse plyes her taske and cannot come.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: For whom then is this wilde Shroue-tuesday kept?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: See King of gloomie shades what soules resort,
To this thy most iust, and least-fying court.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Stay, since our Iayle is with braue-fellowes storde,
Bid Charon that no more yet come aboard.
Seeing our Iudges of hell here likewise are
Sit: call a Sessions: set the soules to a barre.
Minos (the iust:) Rhadamanth (the temperate.)
And Aeacus (the seuere,) each take his state.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Not an officer here?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A Fury.

sp.speaker: 3. Iud.
sp.l: Make an Oyes?

sp.speaker: Fury.
sp.p: Oyes! All manner of soules, if they loue their owne quietnes, keepe out of hell, vnlesse they haue horrible businesse at this infernall sessions, ypon paine of being damnably plagude for their lustines. Back there, let those shackeld rake-hels shew their faces.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Roome here, we must come into the court within.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What damned fiends are those dare make this noise?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: A Iury of Brokers impanelde, and deepely sworne,
To passe on all the villaines in hell.

sp.speaker: Rhad.
sp.l: Euill-Conscience be their keeper.

sp.speaker: Fury.
sp.l: Looke to the Iury: Euill-Conscience looke to the Brokers.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Now proceede.

sp.speaker: Aeac.
sp.l: Stay, let the King of Ghosts haue first a vew
Of those who are doom'd to paines horrid, but new.
Then produce those who came to your prison vntryed.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Peace there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Heres one, hels tortures does deride.— Rauillac.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Arraigne me, rend me peece-meale, ile confesse nothing.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Peace, thou shalt ball thy throate out.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Merciles hangmen! to tiranize ouer so braue a Roman spirit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ho, ho, what country diuell is this?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Thine owne.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: A french.
The eagerest blood hound that ere came from thence;
Is there a King to be murdred, whilest he does stand
Colossus-like, supporting a whole land,
And when by his fall that Land most feares a wracke,
Send forth this diuell; his name is Rauillac.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: Rauillac: I am Rauillac, that laughes at tortures, spurnes at death, defies all mercy: Iybbets, racks, fires, pincers, scalding oyle, wilde-horses, I spit in the face of all.

sp.speaker: our
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: No: were my tongue torne out with burning flesh-hookes, Fames 1●00. tonges shall thunder out Rauillaes name, extoll it, eternise it, 〈◊〉 it! Canonise it: oh!

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Downe with this diuell to'th dunge on, there let him houle.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Worlds shall applaud my Act, and crowne my soule.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Another.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Come, you leane dog.—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: One drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Whats he? what staruelings this?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: One that lacks a medicine for hunger: I am falne away.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: From heauen.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: To'th common Iayle with him.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: He must feede on beggeries basket: leaue balling serra.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Shall I be vndon for a little drinke.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No, thart vndon for drinking.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Starue him away—
What was he when he liu'de.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A prodigall:
Who (in one yeare,) spent on whores, fooles and slaues,
An Armies maintenance, now begges for cromes, and raues
To see his sumptuous buildings, pastures, woodes,
That stood in vplands, dround in Rhenish floodes.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Is here all?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: All! no, the Arch-helhond's here.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What Peter Goner's this?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Speake softly, within an inch of giuing fire, within an inch.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Had all thy gray diuells in their highest lust sat,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: T' haue litterd furies, they could not haue begot.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: One to match this: ith' darke he groapd damnation,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Now, now.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Digd cellars to find where hel stood and has found it
There was but one villany vnborne, and he crownd it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: So: all the billets lye close; glorious bonfire? pontificall bonfire; braue heads to contriue this, gallant soules to conspire in't, resolute hand to seale this with my blood, through fire, through flint; ha, ha, ha, whither fly my selfe to heauen, friends to honour, none to the halter, enemies to massacre, ha ha, dismall tragicall Comedy now?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What does he?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: As he thinkes, giuing fire to powder;
Nere in any land could diuels haue found, such walkes,
As he was beating out.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: His name.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Guy Eaulx.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Who cals? damnation stops throate.

sp.speaker: 3. Iud.
sp.l: Let it stop thine.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Am I betrayd? giue fire, now, now, giue fire.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Te burne thine owne soule villaine.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Pay him his hire:
He has a desperate rakehels face.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Had his plot tane fire,
One real me before any other had doomesday seene,
Kings who in tombes lay at rest had wakened beene,
He was within 12. howers of he wing downe
A whole land at one blow, and at once drowne
In a flood of flames, an Ark-roiall with his whole fleete,
Of nobilitie and clergy: in a leaden sheete
Law and her children had bin hotly wrap'd;
Millons ere this had in our iayle bin clap'd,
For damned Arts not known now, which had then
Bin rise, but now lye dead (th' Acts with the men.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Make much of this our ningle: for the rest
Deliuer'em to our head-hangman.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: In a twinckling.

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: How applaudes Pluto
Our enginous tortures, and most rigorous doome?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Minos, thy doome is iust;— But your all-fac'de Caitiffs.)
sp.l: What fish in your infernall Nets, Drew you vp
ith Naples Court, Citie and Frierie?
We chard'de you saile thither: Is mischiefs Riuer there drie?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Drie, No: Fat preyes for hell we all did meete,
In Court, Citie, Countrey, Nay, in euery streete,
In euery house, within-him, and without-him.
Hee that wore best cloathes, had some Diuell about him:
Courtiers from Naples hither in sholes are come,
Some for Ambition, for Flattery, and Enuie some:
Some, who (each meale) eate subiects vp, and wore,
Whole Families in their shoo-strings, such, and others more,
Being here, haue bene examining (euer since
They came) by Hells-clarke, (spotted-Conscience.)

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: Till the next Sessions, these wee must deferre.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: None come fro'th Citie, so many bad being there!

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Yes, (King of endles horror) see who's here: Barteruile

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Rich-men in hel! they are welcom, whats the gray beard

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.p: One that can buy thee and ten such as thou art out of thy Sea-coale-pits here. Is not this Newcastle?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No couetous wretch: tis Hell, thy blacke-soules prison.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Soule in prison! I neuer had any soule to speake on.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Now thou shalt finde th'ast one.

sp.speaker: Rar:
sp.l: Can Angells Bayle mee?

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: Not all the wealth which the worlds back does beare
Can Bayle thy wretched soule hence, Now tis here.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: A thousand Pounds.—

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.l: Where ist foole?

sp.speaker: Rhad:
sp.l: Thy wealths now gone,
Thy hands still catch at bags, but they gripe none.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: What's this?—

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Aeac.
sp.l: Ayre, shadowes, things Imaginary:
That is thy Torment now, which was thy Glory.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.p: If you giue me bags full of Saw-dust, in stead of money, my Ghost shall walke.

sp.speaker: 3. Iud:
sp.l: To thy grim Father of Hell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, to my olde brother, Syr Achitophell Pinch gut shall I: shall I?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Hence with him the, Churl's mad:
In Lethes-flood drownd all the wealth hee had.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My chaine, Let me hang in chaines, so it bee my
Golde chaine; Theeues, theeues, theeues.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Throwe him head-long into our boyling-Lake,
Where molten Golde runnes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: His thirst it cannot slake,
Seas could not quench his dropsie: Golde to get
Hee would hang a Citie, statue a Countrey. Euen yet
Raues hee for Bonds and incombers: to saue whose soule,
(Tho hee fed none liuing) Saw-sages were his dole.

div.stage: A confused noyse to come pressing in.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: What coyle is that?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Tis a burning zeale must consume the wicked, and therefore I will not bee kept out, but will chastize and correct the foule Fiend.

sp.speaker: 3. Iud.
sp.l: Whats this blacke Incubus?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: An Arch great Puritane once.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha! How! a Puritane?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: An Arch-great Puritane! How comes thy soule so little.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: I did exercise too much with a liuely Spirit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Are there any more of his Synagogue?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Yes, a whole Hoy-full are Landed.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ply
sp.l: Are they all so blacke as he is?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Worse.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Syrra, why being a Puritane is your soule so black?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Wee were all smoakt out of our owne Countrey, and sent to Rotterdam.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: How camst thou lame and crooked, why do'st halt?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: All the brethren and sisters for the better part are crooked, and halt: for my owne part, I neuer went vpright.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: And yet a puritane? hence with him.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Alacke!
How can I choose but halt, goe lame, and crooked?
When I pulld a whole church downe vpon my backe.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Hence with him, he will pull all hell downe too.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Let in the brethren, to confound this wicked assembly,

sp.speaker: 3. Iud.
sp.l: Thrust him out at hell gates.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Theile confound our kingdome,
If here they get but footing: rise therefore, away;
Keepe the Iurie of brokers till our next court day.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Adiourne this.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: O yes! Sessions is deferd
Because of Puritanes, Hell cannot be cleerd.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Set forward to our Hall paued all with brasse,
Iudges we thanke you: let our officers drinke,
I'th bottome of hells celler, for their good seruice.
Since to this heigth our Empyre vp you reare,
Hell shall hold triumphes, and (that's don,) prepare,
Agen to walke your circuites o're the earth,
Soules are hells Subiects, and then grones our mirth.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: IF't be not good, the Diuell is in't, (they say,)
The Diuell was in't, this then is no good play
By that conclusion, but hereby is meant,
If for so many nones, and midnights spent
To reape three howres of mirth, our haruest-seede
Lyes still and rot. The Diuell in't then indeed▪
Much Labour, Art, and Wit, make vp a Play
As it does a Ship, yet both are cast away,
(When brauely they haue past the humorous Seas)
At landing, What black fates curseth both these?
Sayle it, or sinck it, now tis forth, and nere
The Hauen at which it longs t'ariue: if there
It suffers wrack, the spitefuller Rockes shoote forth,
Yet non may bring it home laden with much worth.
By your wonted gentle gale, (sweete as the Balme,)
Or by extending faire liberall Palme.
To fan away all stormes, if you see it lowers,
The ayre shall ring thankes, but the glory's yours.
